story:
Kadın Orkestra Şefi'ni destekleyin!

(scroll down for english)

Merhaba, ben Nisan. Şu an City University of New York - Queens College'de, Maestro Maurice Peress'in sınıfının tek orkestra şefliği öğrencisi olarak eğitim alıyorum. Buraya kadar her şey güzel.

Orkestra şefliği eğitimi zorlu olduğu kadar heyecanlı bir süreç. Özellikle yurtdışında okuyorsanız bir takım zorluklara katlanmalı ve heyecanınızı kaybetmemelisiniz. Ancak işin maddi boyutu beni çok zorluyor. Bu kampanya, bu nedenle başladı.

Bir devlet üniversitesi olan City University of New York'ta, destek bursuyla okuyorum. Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı Müzik Vakfı'ndan aldığım bursla ilk dönemimi tamamladım. Okuluma devam edebilmem için gerekli olan bütçeye ise maalesef sahip değilim. Bu arada, çalışma iznim olmadığından çalışamadığımı da eklemem gerekli. Kısacası eğitimimi tamamlayabilmem için farklı kaynaklar bulmam gerekmekte. Örneğin Indiegogo gibi.

Siz de katkıda bulunarak, Türkiye'nin ilk klasik batı müziği kadın orkestra şefi İnci Özdil'den ve Carnagie Hall'da konser veren ilk Türk kadın şef Sera Tokay'dan sonra, benim de ülkemizin üçüncü kadın orkestra şefi olmama yardımda bulunabilirsiniz. Çünkü dünyanın daha çok müziğe, Türkiye'nin daha çok kadın orkestra şefine ihtiyacı var. Hem de çok daha.

****************

1991 yılında İstanbul'da doğan Nisan Ak, lise öğrenimini İstanbul Avni Akyol Anadolu Güzel Sanatlar Lisesi'nde tamamladı. Özel yetenek sınavında birincilik ile %100 burslu kabul edildiği Bilgi Üniversitesi Kompozisyon bölümünden, 2014 yılında bölüm birinciliği ve yüksek onur öğrencisi derecesiyle mezun oldu. Nisan, Türkiye'nin üçüncü kadın orkestra şefi olmak üzere eğitimine City University of New York - Queens College'de, Maestro Murice Peress'in sınıfında devam ediyor.


Support A Woman Conductor!

Hello, I'm Nisan. Currently, I am studying at the City University of New York – Queens College, Aaron Copland School of Music in Orchestral Conducting masters program with Maestro Maurice Peress.

Orchestral conducting education is both exciting and challenging. Yet, it gets more challenging if you are studying abroad. In order to not to loose the excitement, you have to have financial stability. That is why this campaign has started.

I am a scholarship student at the City University of New York. I have completed my first semester with the scholarship that the Nejat F. Eczacıbaşı Music Foundation awarded me. But I don't have the budget to continue my education here in the United States. By the way, I should mention that I don't have a work permit as well. To sum up, in order to complete my education I have to find different sources. Like indiegogo!

You can help me to be the third woman conductor inTurkish History by donating to my cause. The world needs more music, and Turkey needs more woman conductors. A lot more.

****************

Nisan Ak, who born in 1991, completed her high school education in Istanbul Fine Arts High School. She was accepted to Istanbul Bilgi University's composition department as the top incoming student with 100% scholarship, and then graduated as a high honor student with the highest class ranking. Nisan continues her studies at City University of New York – Queens College in Maestro Maurice Peress's class.

story:
Campaign Summary 

While TU will continue to develop and distribute intellectual content for students, we aim to grow from a newspaper to something bigger and broader: a force for creating and maintaining an Objectivist student movement. We aim to help new and established clubs that are interested in promoting Rand's ideas ground themselves as thriving organizations with a real presence on their respective campuses.

In order to make that happen, we need your help. With your support, we can launch projects that will both draw student interest and connect young Objectivist leaders with each other.

What We Need 

“We're expanding our mission from simply producing a newspaper to creating and sustaining an Objectivist student movement. To make this a reality, we are hiring our first ever full-time staff member. We're very fortunate that Brittney Rivera has agreed to join our team.” – Jared Seehafer, TU Board Member

We’re seeking to raise $20k via this campaign to help fund both our projects and Brittney Rivera’s salary through the Fall 2013 semester. We’ve already received a generous donation from an Objectivist donor to match the first $15,000 raised during this campaign. The bulk of project funding will go toward two major related projects: the TU/ARI leadership seminar, where Objectivist student leaders from across the nation will receive the training and motivation necessary to jumpstart awareness on their respective campuses, and the Egoistic Morality campaign speaking event. The speaking event will feature a prominent Objectivist intellectual, speaking on the virtues of egoism to an audience at one of the most prominent and influential universities in the nation.

The culmination of these projects is expected to generate serious media buzz, inspiring a new generation of student activists to emerge. 

The Impact

Donations will have a direct impact on the present student culture. Funds allow us to distribute issues of our print newspaper, host exciting events, offer internships to young writers and market Objectivism on college campuses nationwide. Since the founding of The Undercurrent, we've distributed hundreds of thousands of copies of our paper on campuses across the country, and we've seen many of our student writers go on to do fantastic things, such as starting their own companies or working as intellectuals for The Ayn Rand Institute.

“Brittney was until recently the leader of one of the most successful campus clubs in America, at The University of Texas at Austin, where she organized some very successful events, including talks and debates with speakers from the Ayn Rand Institute and the Center for Industrial Progress. We could tell from this and from her online presence that she was an enthusiastic and competent activist leader, and one who was ready to take on bigger and better challenges. Moreover, we've been consistently impressed by her drive, her follow-through, her charm and her passion for communicating Objectivist ideas.” – Jason Crawford, TU Board Member

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Help us get the word out! Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this fundraiser link via FB, Twitter and email. Tell your like-minded friends about this fundraiser and encourage them to donate and share the link.

*View our Fall 2013 projects proposal by clicking on the "Gallery" tab. 

*Please note: Our highest perk covers travel within the continental United States.

story:
My name is Boban Markovic. I am currently studying at the American University in Bulgaria. I am going to graduate in May, with a double degree in Political Science & International Relations and Business Administration, with a minor in Economics. I have been accepted to the world's top graduate programs in International Affairs, such as Johns Hopkins (SAIS), George Washington (Elliott School), American University (SIS), SciencesPo (PSIA) and the Hertie School of Governance. Johns Hopkins has always been my dream school, and I worked hard to get into it. I'm very close now, but I still need your support. Big achievements are made one small step at the time. Every step counts. I am asking you to help me with my final steps and to contribute to my graduate education.
************************************************************************

"During his entire career at AUBG, Boban has been a leader. He is highly regarded and respected by our entire campus community--his fellow students, the faculty and the administration."
                - Michael W. Easton
                  President of the American University in Bulgaria

************************************************************************


WHO IS BOBAN?

Although my parents planned for me to be a carpenter, I have long dreamed of an education and experience which would shape me as an outstanding person, a worthy citizen and a changemaker. Today, I am graduating from American University in Bulgaria (AUBG) as the Presidential Medalist, with Magna Cum Laude and double degree in Political Science & International Relations and Business Administration.

I was born in 1991, in the times of war, in a family of humble laborers living in a small town of Priboj, on the border of Serbia, Bosnia and Montenegro, Ever since I was in primary school, I have been determined to live the change I want to see in the world. At 17, I received the US State Department Scholarship for Exchange and Education as one of the 50 future leaders from Serbia and Montenegro. At 18, I received President Obama’s Award for community service and contribution to society and Rotary Club’s recognition for outstanding academics and citizenship. At 19, I welcomed a group of over 60 American students and professors to my small hometown. Serbian Philanthropic Forum recognized my twin brother and me as ''the bright future of philanthropy.'' Currently, I am serving as the Representative to the Board of Trustees at AUBG. I worked every summer around 15 hours a day to be able to graduate as the first family member with a college degree. Now, it’s time to move forward with your support!


CITIZEN OF THE WORLD

“I am not an Athenian or a Greek, but a citizen of the world”(Socrates)

 Receiving a US State Department Scholarship as one of 50 young leaders from Serbia and Montenegro gave me an opportunity to study abroad and piqued my passion for service to such a beautiful yet esoteric idea of international community. A year spent in Washington State challenged me to act as an ambassador among peers from more than 30 countries. Through a number of presentations about Serbia, for instance, I convinced a group of 60 students and professors to visit my hometown in the hope of showing them that the Balkans is more than a mere slaughterhouse. I was honored by the Rotary Club, for outstanding citizenship and academics and the community engagement as a foreign student. My devotion to the local community was best reflected through more than a hundred hours of volunteer work in the local charity and development organizations. At the end of my year abroad, I received President Obama’s award for community service and contribution to society and a thank note from the Presidential Council on Service and Civic Participation. For my contribution to international education, I was granted membership in the Phi Beta Delta Honor Society for International Scholars. These experiences inspired me to continue serving the idea of community and to build bridges, through diplomacy, between people who seem to share little more than misunderstanding. With your help, Johns Hopkins School of Advance International Studies will provide me with knowledge, tools and connections to continue doing so effectively.

*my friends from Washington, in my hometown in Serbia

ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENTS

 “Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.” (Mandela)

At the American University in Bulgaria (AUBG), I have built strong academic foundations and worked as a research and teaching assistant in politics and finance. For my academic achievement and research contribution, I have received European Stipend two times in a row. I sought a balance between theory and practice that led me to chair and organize a number of simulations of international institutions, such as Model UN. I also organized and led our college’s first Jessup International Law Moot Court team. Since then, I have been fortunate enough to analyze developments of international relations and politics by publishing articles in the Fair Observer. Based on my writing on the Serbian prospects toward NATO membership, International Security and Affairs Center granted me a study trip to NATO Headquarters and the Senate of Czech Republic, which was the presiding country of the EU at the moment. Discussion with high officials and diplomats reassured me that my passion for diplomacy and international service is long-lasting.

*Serbian students at the American University in Bulgaria

SERVING THE COMMUNITY

“How wonderful it is that nobody need wait a single moment before starting to improve the world” (A. Frank)

Aside of my academic interests and professional engagement, I have seen steps at the local level as vital for the lasting change. In my first year of college, I spent almost every Friday working with kids deprived of parental care, to empower them to present their full potential, performing at a community concert. At 18, I received funding from the American Council  to organize the first School Parliament in my hometown and engage the youth in the community projects. For a short time I have organized run-change volunteer campaign which gathered ethnically diverse young people of Priboj to work towards achieving the same goal – better community.  Although it was only a small step, it showed the importance of mutually beneficial projects for development of small communities. 


PHILANTHROPY

“We make a living by what we get. We make a life by what we give.” (Churchill)

Besides being one of the youngest owners of the organ donation card in Serbia, I am also a regular blood donor. I have donated blood ten times in the past four years, and my aim is to donate hundred times in my lifetime. Two years ago along with my twin brother, I donated a set of books for international education and placement exams to the library in our hometown. Our goal was to emphasize the importance of international education. A year ago, to the same library, we donated a hundred titles more, related to social development, entrepreneurship, language learning, world literature, and leadership. After recently donating a set of Harvard Business Review books to the local Youth Center to stimulate entrepreneurship, Serbian Philanthropic Forum recognized our work as ''the bright future of philanthropy.'' Although I'm still an undergraduate student, I have already pledged small amounts of money to my university.

I believe that every time I get something, I should also give back.


MY FUTURE

“The whole world steps aside for the man who knows where he is going”

I believe that graduate school will help me extend my knowledge of the art and science of international affairs and diplomatic practice, and help me strengthen analytical and diplomatic skills, which are sought for in my region and beyond. After completing my graduate program, I plan to work on post-intervention development in societies torn apart by difference, on questions of assistance in their movement toward democratic stability, and on novel notions like jus post bellum. In the long run, my plan is to start Markovich Brothers Foundation for Education and Development which would give the opportunity to disadvantaged to make change in their lives and impact in their communities. With such hope, never dreamt of in my small town, I believe I can make a contribution to the world.  If you support me, I am sure I will.


PERSONAL EFFORT AND SCHOLARSHIPS

Studying outside of Serbia, I am not eligible for any national scholarships. Also, since Serbia is not member of the European Union, and it's not considered as a developing country anymore, I am not eligible for almost any scholarships coming from these sources.  To be able to complete my undergraduate studies, I have been working in restaurants and cleaning windows every summer, 15 hours a day.

This summer I am going to work again to make some money for graduate school. With your help, I will make enough! Johns Hopkins SAIS offered me 50% waiver on tuition ($22K) for the first year. Depending on GPA, the waiver can be the same for the second year. Also, I am eligible to take $40K in form of a student loan for the next two years. That leaves me only $33K away from covering the estimated costs. For more info on tuition and fees, please click here.  


*With the Serbian Crown Prince | *With the Bulgarian President | *With the Bulgarian Princess

WHAT OTHERS SAY

Without having received scholarships, I wouldn't be where I am right now. Upon enrolling at AUBG, I have received institutional aid and the Open Society Institute scholarship. For my continuous contribution to the AUBG community and society in general, I have received the New York Area Alumni Scholarship in 2013 as well as the AUBG Alumni Scholarship for innovative ideas for change in 2012. In addition, I am a recipient of two European Stipends for academic excellence and one European Research Award.

************************************************************************

“Thank you for your devotion to service and for doing all you can to shape a better tomorrow for our great Nation” 
                               - President Barack Obama (Award letter)
*************************************************************************
  • To see my Curriculum Vitae, please visit my linkedin profile.


Thank you for your effort and contribution!

WHAT OTHERS SAY 
Without having received scholarships, I wouldn't be where I am right now. Upon enrolling at
AUBG, I have received institutional aid and the Open Society Institute scholarship. For my continuous contribution
to the AUBG community and society in general, I have received the New York Area Alumni Scholarship in
2013 as well as the AUBG Alumni
Scholarship for innovative ideas for change in 2012. In addition, I am a recipient of two European
Stipends for academic excellence and one European
Research Award.************************************************************************
“Thank you for your
devotion to service and for doing all you can to shape a better tomorrow for
our great Nation”                                - President Barack Obama
(Award letter)
*************************************************************************To see my Curriculum Vitae, please visit my linkedin profile.
Thank you for your effort and contribution!

story:
"The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they don't have any."-Alice Walker

 

Women growing up in this day and age receive a message of disempowerment from the mass media. We are surrounded with images of photo-shopped models, exploitation of the female form through sexual objectification, and the message that a woman's worth stems from her beauty.  Many of these messages are internalized by young women from a young age through the constant bombardment of the entertainment industry. The internalization of these messages come out through self esteem issues, lack of confidence, eating disorders, and fear of asserting oneself as a leader.  I passionately believe we need a change for the health of our young women and the world at large.  This is why the work being done at North Star Quest Camp is so important.

 

My name is Hanna Nielsen and I will be a counselor this year at North Star Quest Camp (NSQ). NSQ tries to help young ladies in their transition from great girls, to wonderful women.  Women of all ages including high school and college aged counselors, lead entertaining and meaningful workshops ranging from serious topics, such as sexuality and menstruation, to more light hearted topics, such as yoga and trust games. Counselors also lead the girls in enlightening group discussions and other fun activities to support the campers in their Quest. They spend five days at beautiful Camp Mattole, exploring the issues and pressures they face in our culture and learning the skills needed to develop their own values and stay afloat.

 

Our campers are mostly Humboldt girls, and at least two-thirds of them receive some kind of scholarship.  In 2010 our sliding scale slid right down to $0 for 33 girls, because we will not turn anyone away for lack of funds.  The cost to send one girl to camp is $550.00. Most of the wonderful women involved in running this camp are doing it out of passion and are receiving little to no monetary compensation. This is truly a not for profit (monetary profit that is) endeavor. 

 

We are very behind on our fundraising goal to make camp possible. I am trying to raise $550.00 by the end of the month to provide scholarship money in the amount of one camper.  I strongly believe in this cause and think we need more programs like this. No amount is too small to donate. If you can afford to contribute any amount you will truly be making a difference in a small program that makes a large difference in young girls lives.

story:
TAX-DEDUCTIBLE & GOES DIRECTLY TO THE CLINICS!

Who We Are

We are a group of college students with a mission on our minds and a calling in our hearts. We are part of the Baylor University Medical Humanities Program, in Waco, Texas. 

The Waco Family Health Center

Waco’s Family Health  Center is a Federally Qualified Health Center set up to care for the underserved in Waco and  McLennan County. With a poverty rate that  fluctuates around 30% in Waco, FHC is responsible for approximately 50,000 patients per year.  Of those, 21,000 are pediatric patients. The Medical Humanities Program has been able to recruit high achieving premedical students from all over the university and train them as volunteers for FHC’s twelve satellite clinics. 

And That Is Where We Come In


Last year, under the guidance of the Medical Humanities program, Alpha Epsilon Delta—a Baylor University student organization—paired up with Waco Family Health Center South 18th Clinic to provide books to all pediatric patients that walked through its humble doors. The students managed to bring in more than a thousand books for the small clinic, guaranteeing that every child left with a smile on their face and a book in hand. The project was so successful that the Family Health Center asked us expand the mission in both scope and practice to include the remaining eleven clinics in the Waco area. Medical Humanities created a team of individuals—driven to touch the lives of the next generation and to serve a community that has become a second-home—to tackle this project. The goal to acquire books was soon realized. Half-Price Books in Dallas, Texas donated over 21,000 books—one for each pediatric patient! Suddenly, the goal of getting a book into the hands of every child was accomplished. Since then, the mission has evolved to create children’s plays areas, which would incorporate books, into every Family Health Center clinic!

This Is Where You Come In...

We have already completed the construction of a children's play area in the waiting rooms of the South 18th and MLK clinics, but more remains to be done! Ten Family Health Center satellite clinics have yet to be touched by this incredible project, and they need your help in financing the play areas!

The Impact

According to the National Center for Education Statistics, almost two-thirds of American low-income families do not own books for their children. Books serve as inspiration for dreams and as gateways for journeys; they're important not only for the development of a child's intellect but also the development of a child's perspective, creativity, and imagination.

Children who are exposed to reading have higher aptitude for learning in general. Numerous studies have shown that students who are exposed to reading before preschool are more likely to do well in all facets of formal education —it teaches children the ability to grasp abstract concepts, apply logic in various scenarios, and utilize good judgment.

With your help, we can create children's play areas to distribute more than 20,000 books to Family Health Center clinics located throughout the Waco community, fostering an environment dedicated to nurturing the minds of young children. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As college students, we understand that not everyone is financially able to support our cause. Any support—whether it be sharing this campaign, encouraging our team to keep striving towards our goal, or sending a prayer our way—is greatly appreciated! Books don't grow on trees, and although we have more than 20,000, we don't necessarily have an unlimited supply; so if you would like to donate books, feel free to contact Kathleen_Marcos@baylor.edu or Andrew_Orr@baylor.edu.

Again, thank you so much for your time and support!

story:
Just $25 dollars can DOUBLE the fruits and vegetables purchased by one low-income family for an entire month.

Food can change lives, and farmers markets are one of the best ways to connect people with healthy, locally grown food. 

Low-income customers who buy fruits and vegetables at the Columbia Heights farmers market with Federal nutrition benefits like food stamps can participate in our matching funds program.

        $5 in food stamps = $10 in fruits and vegetables

        $10 in food stamps = $20 in fruits and vegetables

This makes healthy eating much easier for low-income families, and helps them stretch their food budgets.

And the program doesn’t just help low-income families! It's good for the local economy, too. Helping low-income market customers also helps the locally owned businesses and small farms that sell at our market; these customers made up 8% of total 2013 sales for our farmers.

Here’s where you come in:

In order to help low-income families and our local farmers, we need to ensure this program is funded for the entire summer, which means raising $10,000.

Demand always exceeds our supply, and we rely on individual donors to fund this program. Your donation will go directly to support the matching funds program.

Every donation helps. Even if you can only give a little, please donate today.

In their own words:

"The matching funds program is beautiful. It really helps senior citizens on a fixed income who have limited resources." 

"The matching funds program gives me more money to spend on good, healthy food for the kids." 

More information:

Columbia Heights is one of the District's most socioeconimically diverse neighborhoods, and the Marketplace has one of the most robust programs for low-income families in the city. In the past two years alone the market has helped over 1,200 families stretch their food budgets and buy healthy, local food.

Last year, one in five dollars of the Women, Infants, and Children (WIC)  Farmers Market Nutrition Program spent in all of Washington, DC were spent at the Columbia Heights Market.

CHCM is a 501(c)(3) non-profitorganization that operates one of the largest and most vibrant farmers markets in Washington, DC. CHCM is committed to increasing access to fresh, sustainably produced, local food and building a healthier community in the heart of the nation's capital.

story:
One in five Zimbabwean children is an orphan, thanks largely to AIDS.  The country's economy is in shambles and the needs are huge.

Hands of Hope runs 20 small-group homes (8-12 kids) for orphans and a feeding program for 2,000 kids in and around Harare, Zimbabwe's capital.  It's a Bay Area nonprofit operating with local Zimbabwean partners. 

 My church, Menlo Park Presbyterian, is sending a team in late August to 

1) run a weeklong summer camp for the kids 

2) deliver several hundred pounds of supplies unavailable in Harare

3) help kids with their English (Most speak Shona as a first language)

4) assess needs and determine how we can help in the future. 

I'm going too. My recent bout with breast cancer has given me a heart to work with others. I When I lost my hair to chemo in January, I felt stigmatized and ashamed. Finally I felt I had to own my baldness. I'm doing that by wearing my baldness with pride to help children with far worse challenges. You can help by  putting my baldness out there for 15 minutes, an hour, a day. The proceeds will fund my mission with Hands of Hope in Zimbabwe.

story:
We're live at www.tinkeringlabs.com!

Some of you have asked if it's still possible to order a Catalyst now that the campaign is over.  You bet it is!  You can find the Electric Motors Catalyst, Booster Pack, Class Pack, and 10-Pack at www.tinkeringlabs.com. Hope to see you there!


Thank You, Tinkerers!

Thanks to all of you, our campaign surpassed our goals in pretty much every category: the number of countries reached, the number of schools and homeschool groups that will be using the Catalyst, and the number of families who will be Tinkering at home. And of course, the total funds raised, which gives us the fuel to keep the Tinkering Labs engine moving.  Thank you!

We'll now be putting the finishing touches on the Electric Motors Catalyst and Booster Pack, ramping up production so we can get all those kits out to all of you, and continuing work on our new Catalysts.

If you or a friend would like to pre-order another item, they are available at www.tinkeringlabs.com now.

An please stay in touch with us!  Email us at tinkering@tinkeringlabs.com with any ideas, questions, or tales of Tinkering.  And connect with us on Facebook and Twitter.

We hope you all have a wonderful summer full of Tinkering (or winter, for you southerners!). I know we will - thanks to you.

With gratitude,

The Tinkering Labs Team:  Matt, Gever, Cari, Nik, Chris, Ted, and John

Tinkering For All!

As founder of Tinkering School, The Institute for Applied Tinkering and Brightworks, 10 years of Tinkering experience has taught me that kids can build anything, and through building, learn anything.

But not every kid can come to our school or camps. So we’ve started Tinkering Labs to make the problem-solving skills, knowledge and confidence that Tinkering enables available to all kids. Help us bring the pure joy of invention to a kid in your life by supporting the creation of our first kit: The Tinkering Labs ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST. Thank you, and #TinkeringForAll!

Gever Tulley
Founder of Tinkering Labs

NEW: Get the Booster Pack for only $10!

We're in the last few days of the campaign, and we want to offer something special just for our early supporters. We call it the Electric Motors Booster Pack, and it’s available for just $10 through Sunday, May 31.

The Booster Pack includes a high-torque gear motor, two new wheels, three LEDs (white, red, and green) and conductive copper tape. It also comes with additional Challenge Cards that open a wide range of new capabilities for kids to explore.

  • THE GEAR MOTOR enables inventions that need more power or lower rotational speeds, including “creeping” robots, “chairlifts” that can climb up a string, and a huge variety of drawing machines. 
  • LED LIGHTS let kids build blinkers and dimmers, and the electrically minded might even figure out how to make a light glow without using a battery at all (hint: a motor can be a generator!). 
  • COPPER TAPE creates an enormous new range of electrical connections, and is especially useful for switches that make things that start and stop or blink or jiggle.
  • NEW CHALLENGES inspire even more engaging, creative possibilities!

Just $10 Through Sunday, May 31. For the last few days, the Electric Motors Booster Pack is available to our supporters for only $10. We want all of you to have a chance to add these amazing capabilities to your kits at a price that’s as affordable as possible. The Booster Pack will not be available at this price after the campaign is over. If you pre-ordered a Catalyst or 10-pack, pick up a Booster Pack now to multiply the possibilities!

Why Do Kids Need Tinkering? 

Because they are growing up in a world full of complex problems with no instruction booklet. Kids need experience working independently on open-ended projects that are goal-directed but unscripted.  By activating their hands and their minds, Tinkering helps kids develop the skills, knowledge and grit necessary to become the innovators their generation is going to need. Tinkering develops: 

  • Problem-solving skills
  • Adaptability and resilience
  • Collaboration with peers
  • An intuitive grasp of science, technology, engineering, art and math (STEAM) principles
  • The confidence that only comes from competence

Tinkering succeeds at imparting these skills because it has a secret weapon: it is pure natural fun! Human childhood evolved to make it fun for kids to use their hands and brains to figure out the physical world. Tinkering is literally what kids were born to do.

Introducing Catalyst #1: Electric Motors

Our first Catalyst - Electric Motors - is a kit that makes it easy for parents and teachers to provide their kids with super-fun open-ended learning: what we call Tinkering!
What at first seems like a random set of items (motors, wooden parts, springs and bolts, rubber bands and washable markers) rapidly becomes a platform for innovation in the hands of kids.

What Can You Do With the Electric Motors Catalyst?

You can build a countless number of projects that utilize the power of electric motors. To help you get started, the Catalyst comes with a set of Challenge Cards to inspire kids to explore. Some of the challenges include:

  • Build a machine that draws curvy lines
  • Build a vehicle that moves in a straight line
  • Build a machine that sends a message in Morse Code
  • Make a machine that can scramble an egg
  • Build a machine that can climb a string
  • Create something that makes a loud sound
  • Build a vehicle with a suspension system
  • ...and many more. Here are just a few things kids have come up with so far in our prototype test sessions:


Who is it For?

The kits are designed for boys and girls aged 6-13, but even adults have been known to spend hours Tinkering with the Catalyst. We've spent a great deal of time designing and testing so that any kid — regardless of experience — can engage quickly make something that captures their imagination. Whether a kid is a budding artist, poet, engineer, scientist, athlete, or dreamer, they will love creating things with the Catalyst.

With help from our friends in their homes, schools, scout troops, the Exploratorium, the Boys and Girls Club and Stanford University d.school, we’ve watched hundreds of kids invent using the Electric Motors Catalyst. In every Tinkering session, kids create things we never knew were possible. Who knows what your kids will invent?


Where Can You Use it?

At home, kids have a blast Tinkering on their own or with friends and siblings. In  schools, clubs and other group settings Catalyst 10-packs are a great way to provide students with open-ended learning experiences. The kits are designed for children to be able to work independently without help. The included Challenge and Tip Cards give kids just enough guidance to get started, and they make it easy for any adult to facilitate a Tinkerthon with 20 or more kids!



Why Does the Electric Motors Catalyst Work?

In an ideal Tinkering experience a child has fun right away, runs into problems, solves them, and is then inspired to do more. 10 years of projects and activities have taught us that incorporating the following principles leads to higher engagement and better outcomes:
  • Fast and tweakable: Parts are simple to attach, tweak and take apart so that kids can quickly and easily try different things.
  • Challenges, not instructions: We don't provide step-by-step instructions, but include Challenge and Tip Cards help kids get started and inspire them to create on their own inventions.
  • Real, not imaginary: We use recognizable hardware, tools and materials so that kids easily connect and incorporate the Catalyst with the objects in the world around them.
  • Safe: Carefully planned parts allow for freedom of exploration without the need for adult supervision.
  • Collaborative: Once we’re up and running, kids can join our online community where they can share ideas, learn from others, and provide support.

> SKIP TO "MORE ABOUT THE ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST"


    Why We Need Your Help

    We aim to take our Catalysts worldwide, and we can’t do it without your help. We need to reach our goal of $50,000 in order to purchase parts in bulk, and set up the fulfillment services and strategic partnerships needed to scale. So please help us by contributing today.

    What are the Perks?

    If you contribute today, you have access to some great perks before anyone else. Our focus is on rolling out the Electric Motors Catalyst and the 10-packs, but we also have a number of other ways to show our appreciation for your support including t-shirts, books and memberships in our Design Council. Here are some of our favorites:

    		$25: Limited Edition "Gear Brain" T-shirt
    ONLY 25 AT THIS PRICE!
    Get the official Tinkering Labs T-shirt in whatever size you choose (including kids' & ladies' sizes). Wear the Gear Brain with pride, and share your love of Tinkering with everyone!


    		$39: Electric Motors Catalyst
    Become a founding member of the Tinkering Labs community and get an ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST for a young person in your life, or donate one to an organization that could really use it. 



    		$ 100: Signed Copy of "50 Dangerous Things," Catalyst, and T-Shirt
    ONLY 100 AVAILABLE!
    Get a signed copy of "50 Dangerous Things (You Should Let Your Children Do)," Gever's book that was inspired by his TED talk and was featured in the New York Times this April. With this perk, you also get:
    • The Electric Motors Catalyst
    • The Tinkering Labs T-shirt


    		$200: Join our Design Council and get a  Catalyst Prototype
    LIMITED TO 50.
    The Design Council is the team that brings Catalysts to life. Take part in design and prototype discussions where we evaluate ideas from the Tinkering Labs community and determine which Catalysts to develop next. To help us get started, you'll also get an early prototype version of the Electric Motors Catalyst shipped to you in June — months before everyone else.

    		$329: Homeschoolers Group Pack
    Homeschool groups have asked if a 10-Pack can be divided among 10 families. The original 10-Pack is intended for classroom or group use and is not designed to be divided up. So we’re offering this Group Pack for $329, containing 10 individual ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYSTS. For more than 10 contact us at tinkering@tinkeringlabs.com.

    If you are near San Francisco, you can pick up your Catalysts. Or, add $20 for shipping within the US / $60 international.
    $1,000: Host your Own Tinkerthon
    CURRENTLY LIMITED TO 10.
    Host a Tinkerthon for up to 30 kids led by the Tinkering Labs team for your classroom, after-school program, club or event. A Tinkerthon includes:
    • 10 Electric Motors Catalysts
    • 1 hr of training for teachers and staff
    • 2 hrs of hands-on Tinkering with kids

    We can lead the Tinkerthon online, or please contact us if you'd like us to lead it in person. Travel expenses not included.

    Your Contribution Supports Tinkering Everywhere

    By contributing to our campaign, you're also helping the Institute for Applied Tinkering, a non-profit whose mission is to "explore, develop, and promote new methods for helping children learn using real tools to solve real problems in the real world.” 1% of all contributions (and 1% of all Tinkering Labs sales after the campaign), will be donated to the Institute for Applied Tinkering. 



    How Will We Use the Contributions?

    Your contributions will help us in many ways, from driving down the cost of materials to helping us develop the next set of Catalysts. Here is how it breaks down:


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Please tell your friends and share our mission on social media using IndieGoGo’s sharing tools or the share page on our website. If you know a reporter or blogger, please ask them to cover the story. Tell your schools, scout troops and summer camps. Tell your parents and your in-laws.

    Help us shout it from the rooftops and bring the love of Tinkering to kids worldwide! The mission is #TinkeringForAll


    More About the Electric Motors Catalyst

    What’s In the Box?


    Each Electric Motors Catalyst includes the following pieces:

    1. Custom-designed laser-cut wood parts. The “ladybug platform” inspires kids with an unusual shape and carefully designed arrangement of holes and tabs that makes all kinds of configurations possible.

    2. Electric motors and battery pack. Both are equipped with kid-friendly connectors for high-speed trial and error. Batteries are included.

    3. Real safety glasses. Because safety is a superpower!

    4. Real screwdriver. Having your own real tools is a step toward independence.

    5. Hardware and electrical connectors. Bolts, wing nuts, angle brackets, and springs create an amazing array of ways to assemble inventions and connect electrical circuits. Rubber bands let you connect it all together—and then take it all apart—fast.

    6. Washable markers. Because it's fun to make machines that draw and  it's fun to draw on machines.

    7. Challenge Cards for inspiration and Tip Cards that provide just the right amount of guidance. Can you build a machine that scrambles an egg? Or draws curvy lines? Or sends a message in Morse code? We think you can!

    There are also two drawstring canvas bags to store it all, and batteries are included! 

    *Please note that although our current plan is to include each of these parts as they are described, we are still testing and improving the Catalyst. When we find ways to make it better, we'll make changes.

    What's In a 10-Pack?

    The 10-pack is a great way for schools, after-school programs, clubs and other organizations to get kids Tinkering. Each 10-pack will come packaged in a box that can be used for easy storage and will include 10 sets of the Catalyst parts mentioned above except for the following changes:

    • One set of Challenge and Tip Cards
    • 10 drawstring canvas bags (one for each type of part)

    Challenges, Not Instructions

    Tinkering is not about following directions — it’s about playing, experimenting, and finding your own way. This is what generates excitement in kids, and it’s also the source of learning and emotional benefits.

    So the Electric Motors Catalyst does not come with instructions. But to get things started, it comes with a deck of 20 Challenge Cards that kids, teachers, and parents can use for inspiration. Each challenge is kid-tested and can provide hours of engagement.

    Tips to Help You Along

    All inventors learn from the people around them and those who came before them. To help kids learn some basic building techniques that are useful for any challenge, the Electric Motors Catalyst includes a set of 10 Tip Cards. And we hope that kids will share their own tips online once they have the Catalyst, so that the community of young Tinkerers can learn together.

    Use it Again and Again

    The Electric Motors Catalyst is designed to be used over and over again.  After you've built something, take a picture or video (and please share it with us!), and then take it apart and build something new. Gever always says, "If you have parts, make something. If you have something, take it apart!"


    The Electric Motors Catalyst is Just the Beginning

    The Electric Motors Catalyst is our first, but we have 35 more Catalyst ideas on the drawing board, including:
    • Rubber-Band Power
    • Flight
    • Gears and Levers
    • Optics
    • Gravity Power
    • Sound


    Our Story: 10 Years of Tinkering

    Although Tinkering Labs is new, our history goes back 10 years to the day Gever started Tinkering School in his back yard. Take a look at the journey below:


    And over the years, we've received a lot of press:


    Risks & Challenges

    The biggest risk we face is in the cost of the Catalysts—currently, the parts in each Catalyst cost $40, which does not include assembly, packaging, or mailing. If we can get 1,000 pre-orders for the Electric Motors Catalyst, we can get significant discounts on bulk orders that will allow us to sell these at a price that almost any family, school or after-school program can afford.


    Thank You!

    We want to send a big big THANK YOU to our friends at Brightworks, Tinkering School, the Girl Scouts of San Mateo County, the Exploratorium, Stanford d.school, Mark Day School and the Boys & Girls Clubs of Sonoma Valley for helping us test and improve the Electric Motors Catalyst. Thank you also to TechShop and SF Laser for your help.  You are all awesome Tinkerers!



    Thank you for your support!
    - The Tinkering Labs team



    *International Shipping Details

    Domestic shipping is included in all perks. If you would like us to ship the perks outside of the U.S., please add the following  amounts. You can add it as an additional donation on the screen where you enter your shipping address.

    T-shirt (up to 10) $15
    Catalysts (each) $20
    Catalyst + Signed Book + T-shirt $25
    Catalyst 10-Pack $60
    Tinkering Labs Academy Free
    Patron Free
story_txt:
We're live at www.tinkeringlabs.com!Some of you have asked if it's still possible to order a Catalyst now that the campaign is over.  You bet it is!  You can find the Electric Motors Catalyst, Booster Pack, Class Pack, and 10-Pack at www.tinkeringlabs.com. Hope to see you there!Thank You, Tinkerers!Thanks to all of you, our campaign surpassed our goals in pretty much every category: the number of countries reached, the number of schools and homeschool groups that will be using the Catalyst, and the number of families who will be Tinkering at home. And of course, the total funds raised, which gives us the fuel to keep the Tinkering Labs engine moving.  Thank you!We'll now be putting the finishing touches on the Electric Motors Catalyst and Booster Pack, ramping up production so we can get all those kits out to all of you, and continuing work on our new Catalysts.If you or a friend would like to pre-order another item, they are available at www.tinkeringlabs.com now.An please stay in touch with us!  Email us at tinkering@tinkeringlabs.com with any ideas, questions, or tales of Tinkering.  And connect with us on Facebook and Twitter.We hope you all have a wonderful summer full of Tinkering (or winter, for you southerners!). I know we will - thanks to you.With gratitude,The Tinkering Labs Team:  Matt, Gever, Cari, Nik, Chris, Ted, and John
Tinkering For All!
As founder of Tinkering School, The Institute for Applied Tinkering and Brightworks, 10 years of Tinkering experience has taught me that kids can build anything, and through building, learn anything.

But not every kid can come to our school or camps. So we’ve started Tinkering Labs to make the problem-solving skills, knowledge and confidence that Tinkering enables available to all kids. Help us bring the pure joy of invention to a kid in your life by supporting the creation of our first kit: The Tinkering Labs ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST. Thank you, and #TinkeringForAll!

Gever Tulley 
Founder of Tinkering Labs


NEW: Get the Booster Pack for only $10!

We're in the last few days of the campaign, and we want to offer something special just for our early supporters. We call it the Electric Motors Booster Pack, and it’s available for just $10 through Sunday, May 31.




The Booster Pack includes a high-torque gear motor, two new wheels, three LEDs (white, red, and green) and conductive copper tape. It also comes with additional Challenge Cards that open a wide range of new capabilities for kids to explore.



THE GEAR MOTOR enables inventions that need more power or lower rotational speeds, including “creeping” robots, “chairlifts” that can climb up a string, and a huge variety of drawing machines. 


LED LIGHTS let kids build blinkers and dimmers, and the electrically minded might even figure out how to make a light glow without using a battery at all (hint: a motor can be a generator!). 


COPPER TAPE creates an enormous new range of electrical connections, and is especially useful for switches that make things that start and stop or blink or jiggle.

NEW CHALLENGES inspire even more engaging, creative possibilities!

Just $10 Through Sunday, May 31. For the last few days, the Electric Motors Booster Pack is available to our supporters for only $10. We want all of you to have a chance to add these amazing capabilities to your kits at a price that’s as affordable as possible. The Booster Pack will not be available at this price after the campaign is over. If you pre-ordered a Catalyst or 10-pack, pick up a Booster Pack now to multiply the possibilities!




Why Do Kids Need Tinkering? 




Because they are growing up in a world full of complex problems with no instruction booklet. Kids need experience working independently on open-ended 
projects that are goal-directed but unscripted.  By activating their 
hands and their minds, Tinkering helps kids develop the skills, knowledge and grit necessary to become the innovators their generation is going to need. Tinkering develops: 


Problem-solving skills

Adaptability and resilience


Collaboration with peers

An intuitive grasp of science, technology, engineering, art and math (STEAM) principles

The confidence that only comes from competence





Tinkering succeeds at imparting these skills because it has a secret weapon: it is pure natural fun! Human childhood evolved to make it fun for kids to use their hands and brains to figure out the physical world. Tinkering is literally what kids were born to do. 

Introducing Catalyst #1: Electric Motors


Our first Catalyst - Electric Motors - is a kit that makes it easy for parents and teachers to provide their kids with super-fun open-ended learning: what we call Tinkering!

What at first seems like a random set of items (motors, wooden parts, springs and bolts, rubber bands and washable markers) rapidly becomes a platform for innovation in the hands of kids.
What Can You Do With the Electric Motors Catalyst?

You can build a countless number of projects that utilize the power of electric motors. To help you get started, the Catalyst comes with a set of Challenge Cards to inspire kids to explore. Some of the challenges include: 
Build a machine that draws curvy lines

Build a vehicle that moves in a straight line

Build a machine that sends a message in Morse Code

Make a machine that can scramble an egg

Build a machine that can climb a string

Create something that makes a loud sound

Build a vehicle with a suspension system

...and many more. Here are just a few things kids have come up with so far in our prototype test sessions:





Who is it For?The kits are designed for boys and girls aged 6-13, but even adults have been known to spend hours Tinkering with the Catalyst. We've spent a great deal of time designing and testing so that any kid — regardless of experience — can engage quickly make something that captures their imagination. Whether a kid is a budding artist, poet, engineer, scientist, athlete, or dreamer, they will love creating things with the Catalyst.
With help from our friends in their homes, schools, scout troops, 
the Exploratorium, the Boys and Girls Club and Stanford University 
d.school, we’ve watched hundreds of kids invent using the Electric 
Motors Catalyst. In every Tinkering session, kids create things we never
 knew were possible. Who knows what your kids will invent?



Where Can You Use it?
At home, kids have a blast Tinkering on their own or with friends and siblings. In  schools, clubs and other group settings Catalyst 10-packs are a great way to provide students with open-ended learning experiences. The kits are designed for children to be able to work independently without help. The included Challenge and Tip Cards give kids just enough guidance to get started, and they make it easy for any adult to facilitate a Tinkerthon with 20 or more kids!


Why Does the Electric Motors Catalyst Work?
In an ideal Tinkering experience a child has fun right away, runs into problems, solves them, and is then inspired to do more. 10 years of projects and activities have taught us that incorporating the following principles leads to higher engagement and better outcomes:


Fast and tweakable: Parts are simple to attach, tweak and take apart so that kids can quickly and easily try different things.


Challenges, not instructions: We don't provide step-by-step instructions, but include Challenge and Tip Cards help kids get started and inspire them to create on their own inventions.


Real, not imaginary: We use recognizable hardware, tools and 
materials so that kids easily connect and incorporate the Catalyst with
 the objects in the world around them.


Safe: Carefully planned parts allow for freedom of exploration without the need for adult supervision.


Collaborative: Once we’re up and running, kids can join our online community where 
they can share ideas, learn from others, and provide 
support.

> SKIP TO "MORE ABOUT THE ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST"








Why We Need Your Help
We aim to take our Catalysts worldwide, and we can’t do it without your 
help. We need to reach our goal of $50,000 in order to purchase parts in
 bulk, and set up the fulfillment services and strategic partnerships 
needed to scale. So please help us by contributing today. 
What are the Perks?
If you contribute today, you have access to some great perks before anyone else. Our focus is on rolling out the Electric Motors Catalyst and the 10-packs, but we also have a number of other ways to show our appreciation for your support including t-shirts, books and memberships in our Design Council. Here are some of our favorites: 






$25: Limited Edition "Gear Brain" T-shirt ONLY 25 AT THIS PRICE!Get the official Tinkering Labs T-shirt in whatever size you choose (including kids' & ladies' sizes). Wear the Gear Brain with pride, and share your love of Tinkering with everyone!








$39: Electric Motors CatalystBecome a founding member of the Tinkering Labs community and get an ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYST for a young person in your life, or donate one to an organization that could really use it. 








$ 100: Signed Copy of "50 Dangerous Things," Catalyst, and T-ShirtONLY 100 AVAILABLE!Get a signed copy of  "50 Dangerous Things (You Should Let Your Children Do)," Gever's book that was inspired by his TED talk and was featured in the New York Times this April. With this perk, you also get: 
The Electric Motors Catalyst
The Tinkering Labs T-shirt










$200: Join our Design Council and get a  Catalyst PrototypeLIMITED TO 50.The Design Council is the team that brings Catalysts to life. Take part in design and prototype discussions where we evaluate ideas from the Tinkering Labs community and determine which Catalysts to develop next. To help us get started, you'll also get an early prototype version of the Electric Motors Catalyst shipped to you in June — months before everyone else.








$329: Homeschoolers Group PackHomeschool groups have asked if a 10-Pack can be divided among 10 families. The original 10-Pack is intended for classroom or group use and is not designed to be divided up. So we’re offering this Group Pack for $329, containing 10 individual ELECTRIC MOTORS CATALYSTS. For more than 10 contact us at tinkering@tinkeringlabs.com. If you are near San Francisco, you can pick up your Catalysts. Or, add $20 for shipping within the US / $60 international.







$1,000: Host your Own TinkerthonCURRENTLY LIMITED TO 10.Host a Tinkerthon for up to 30 kids led by the Tinkering Labs team for your classroom, after-school program, club or event. A Tinkerthon includes: 
10 Electric Motors Catalysts
1 hr of training for teachers and staff
2 hrs of hands-on Tinkering with kids

We can lead the Tinkerthon online, or please contact us if you'd like us to lead it in person. Travel expenses not included.




Your Contribution Supports Tinkering Everywhere
By contributing to our campaign, you're also helping the Institute for Applied Tinkering, a non-profit whose mission is to "explore, develop, and promote new methods for helping children learn using real tools to solve real problems in the real world.” 1% of all contributions (and 1% of all Tinkering Labs sales after the campaign), will be donated to the Institute for Applied Tinkering. 



How Will We Use the Contributions?

Your contributions will help us in many ways, from driving down the cost of materials to helping us develop the next set of Catalysts. Here is how it breaks down:


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Please tell your friends and share our mission on social media using IndieGoGo’s sharing tools or the share page on our website. If you know a reporter or blogger, please ask them to cover the story. Tell your schools, scout troops and summer camps. Tell your parents and your in-laws. 
Help us shout it from the rooftops and bring the love of Tinkering to kids worldwide! The mission is #TinkeringForAll

More About the Electric Motors Catalyst
What’s In the Box?




Each Electric Motors Catalyst includes the following pieces:


Custom-designed laser-cut wood parts. The “ladybug platform” inspires kids with an unusual shape and carefully designed arrangement of holes and tabs that makes all kinds of configurations possible.
Electric motors and battery pack. Both are equipped with kid-friendly connectors for high-speed trial and error. Batteries are included.
Real safety glasses. Because safety is a superpower!
Real screwdriver. Having your own real tools is a step toward independence.
Hardware and electrical connectors. Bolts, wing nuts, angle brackets, and springs create an amazing array of ways to assemble inventions and connect electrical circuits. Rubber bands let you connect it all together—and then take it all apart—fast.
Washable markers. Because it's fun to make machines that draw and  it's fun to draw on machines.
Challenge Cards for inspiration and Tip Cards that provide just the right amount of guidance. Can you build a machine that scrambles an egg? Or draws curvy lines? Or sends a message in Morse code? We think you can!

There are also two drawstring canvas bags to store it all, and batteries are included!  
*Please note that although our current plan is to include each of these parts as they are described, we are still testing and improving the Catalyst. When we find ways to make it better, we'll make changes.

10 drawstring canvas bags (one for each type of part)

share it with us!), and then take it apart and build something new. 
Gever always says, "If you have parts, make something. If you have something, 
take it apart!"

Rubber-Band Power
Flight

Optics

Sound

And over the years, we've received a lot of press:

Thank you also to TechShop and SF Laser for your help.  You are all awesome Tinkerers!





Thank you for your support!- The Tinkering Labs team

story:
UPDATE :

Dear Supporters,thank you very much for your contributions towards the crowdfunding campaign "Centre Artistique de Korghogo" !

I am very happy to anounce that we have not just reached, but even exceeded our campaign goal and collected a total of 6.980,00$. The campaing ended on february the 13th and funds have since been transverred to my account. Needless to say the artists and students are delighted and can't wait for the work to beginn.  We paid a visit to the town officials at the beginning of this week to inform them that we will start with the renovation and construction works. They were very happy and gave us the green light. The different craftsmen have also been contacted and work on site bginns this coming monday.So thank you very much once again and be sure to expect more updates as we progress.

All the best from Korhogo,
Christopher

Hello

my name is Chris Biller and I am currently working on an agricultural development project in the north of the Côte d'Ivoire. The project is funded by the German development cooperation and our team’s main office is situated in Korhogo, the capital of the "Savanes" region.

The region is finally starting to recover after several years of political and socio-economic unrest and the recent peacefull elections give hope for  continuous stability. Current development efforts in Korhogo mostly target basic social and market infrastructure. However living standards for the majority of the population are still low and unemployment, especially amongst the youth, is high.

The countries 4th biggest town with around 200.000 inhabitants and an agricultural based economy is the capital of the Senufo people. Traditionaly art has allways played an important role in their culture and the region is well known for its unique music,dance, paintings and weaving. 


What's the story ?

While staying here, I have had the chance to get to know a team of artists who collectively run a local art center called "Centre Artistique de Korhogo".

The place was established in 1998 and one of its main goals is, to offer children and young adults, who have not had the chance to attend or complete school, an alternative education in the arts. It' s a chance for them to get off the streets, to express themselves and to use their energy in a productive way. The creative process provides a sense of serenity and lets the students discover the profound values art conveys. Learning how to master a paintbrush, a pencil, a pair of scissors, a chisel or fire also increases their self-esteem.

At the same time the center serves as a workshop for artists who produce and sell paintings, banners, various calligraphic work, screen prints, decor, wooden or bronze sculptures and "balafons".  

- check the gallery for more pictures !


So far around 130 female and male students have graduated and are now working all over the country - some even set up shop in Tchad and Niger. The students don’t pay any type of enrolment but manage to contribute to the center and even support themselves through the revenues generated from their work in the workshop.

The center was founded by visual artist Soro A. Mamadou aka. SAM, who also does most of the theoretical teaching. Currently two more artists/instructors are part of the core team managing the center: Diabate Bakaramoko who mainly works with bronze and Soro Yalatima who builds balafons. 

- from left to right: Diabate,  Dagnono (supporter of the center),  Soro and SAM


The "Centre Artistique de Korhogo" also provides amateur artists and art enthusiasts a space to unwind and take a break of the daily grind. Throughout the day and especially in the early evening folks gather on the porch or in the backyard to chat, relax and to get inspired.  In this context we also came up with the idea to kick start this project:


What's the money for?

While the income of the workshop allows the artists to make a living, it is not enough to cover the costs of long overdue maintenance and repair work.

  • The main goal is to collect enough funds to fix and protect the buildings wood work which has been damaged by termites and suffers in this the tropical climate. 
  • Further we want to build a roofed shelter in the court for the artists to work under when it's raining and more importantly to dry wood and store building materials.
  • We also want to get a welder to build a metal storage box/cabinet in which valuable materials, art and possibly a computer can be safely locked away at night.
  • If enough money is donated the artists would also like to build a toilet in the backyard as the center currently doesn't have one.   

We solicited a number of craftsmen, got quotations and came up with the table below, which lists the costs for the different measures in order of priority. Much of the man power will by provided by the artists themselves and if the anticipated total amount can't be mobilized, we will focus on the essentail renovations.


Why do we need your support?

Your contributions will come as a huge relief to the artists who are currently not receiving any financial or material support from donors or the government. Also, since the beginning of the crisis more than 10 years ago, tourists who used to be a great source of revenue, have been absent from Korhogo. Assuring the center is in good shape will allow the artists to carry on with their work and it will ensure that new students can be admitted. Last but not least, your funds will help preserve an important cultural space for the people of Korhogo!  

  

...

As campaign manager I will collect the funds and assure the money is used for the intended purposes only. Together with the team I will oversee and document the process. When done, I will write a report which will be shared with everybody who contributed to the project.

with their work and it will ensure that new students can be admitted. Last but not

story:
Short Summary

Hello I am Coryn! Youngest of a family of 6. I come from Portland, Oregon and I have been unschooled all of my life. I have never gone to school for even a single day (unless you count going to play productions at theaters then I go all the time!)

I am trying to earn enough money to fly to Belgium. This will be my first major travel trip. I have only been out of the country once before and that was to Canada. I really want to travel as my older sister has travelled to Australia and Alaska and many other places. I suspect that she passed the travelling itch to me!

 

I was going to go to Liberia, Africa this Summer but my mother had a seizure a month before I was going to go and the hospital bills have kind of just soaked up all of my family's extra money plus I wanted to hang out around and stay close with her while she recovered.

 

The family I was going to stay with has offered to have me to come stay with them in Belgium and I would really like to go. I can't afford it on my own though so any amount you can donate would help so much. Thank you!

What We Need & What You Get

I need $600 to pay for my half of the ticket to Belgium! I am working on house sitting and baby sitting and mowing lawns around the neighberhood and looking for gigs on craigslist but there is not much for a 17 year old who is going to travel in less then 2 months! 

 

My perks!

If you live local then I have quite a few pretty good perks for you! My father is a retired Chiropractor that would be happy to work on you, I can give you a massage, perhaps take your dogs for a walk or house sit for you? 

If you don't live local well there are still lots of options! I can bring you back a speciality from Belgium (perhaps some real Belgian chocolate straight from Belgium or a mug!)

The Impact

If I can earn the $600 for the ticket then I will go to Belgium in September where I will live for close to a month. From there I will either stay in Belgium or possibly go to Liberia, Africa. This will be that trip for me that I remember 10-15 years down the line with fond memories. It will be the trip that I think I will mature from being a teenager tod becoming more of an adult.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate then if you could just share it on your facebook or your twitter or just talk about it with your friends. Even if you can't donate you can still help lots. Thank you so much!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello I am Coryn! Youngest of a family of 6. I come from Portland, Oregon and I have been unschooled all of my life. I have never gone to school for even a single day (unless you count going to play productions at theaters then I go all the time!)
I am trying to earn enough money to fly to Belgium. This will be my first major travel trip. I have only been out of the country once before and that was to Canada. I really want to travel as my older sister has travelled to Australia and Alaska and many other places. I suspect that she passed the travelling itch to me!
 
I was going to go to Liberia, Africa this Summer but my mother had a seizure a month before I was going to go and the hospital bills have kind of just soaked up all of my family's extra money plus I wanted to hang out around and stay close with her while she recovered.
 
The family I was going to stay with has offered to have me to come stay with them in Belgium and I would really like to go. I can't afford it on my own though so any amount you can donate would help so much. Thank you!


What We Need & What You Get
I need $600 to pay for my half of the ticket to Belgium! I am working on house sitting and baby sitting and mowing lawns around the neighberhood and looking for gigs on craigslist but there is not much for a 17 year old who is going to travel in less then 2 months! 
 
My perks!
If you live local then I have quite a few pretty good perks for you! My father is a retired Chiropractor that would be happy to work on you, I can give you a massage, perhaps take your dogs for a walk or house sit for you? 
If you don't live local well there are still lots of options! I can bring you back a speciality from Belgium (perhaps some real Belgian chocolate straight from Belgium or a mug!)


The Impact
If I can earn the $600 for the ticket then I will go to Belgium in September where I will live for close to a month. From there I will either stay in Belgium or possibly go to Liberia, Africa. This will be that trip for me that I remember 10-15 years down the line with fond memories. It will be the trip that I think I will mature from being a teenager tod becoming more of an adult.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate then if you could just share it on your facebook or your twitter or just talk about it with your friends. Even if you can't donate you can still help lots. Thank you so much!

story:
Childhood is under assault. Quality family time is compromised by extended parental work hours; pressure has increased for kids to “specialize” and compete; and the constant presence of TV, video games, and social media is rapidly changing  social norms and undermining the experience of childhood. Consider that . . .  

We believe deeply that childhood matters. As a team of pediatricians, counselors, educators, and writers, we’re concerned about how changing norms impact kids today, and we advocate a return to an age-old truth confirmed by recent research: To flourish, kids need REAL face-to-face connection. It’s also true that the less time kids spend authentically interacting with others, the less practice they get learning how to communicate, negotiate, and mediate the inevitable conflicts of life. This leads to dire consequences such as . . .

Above all else, kids need REAL relationships in their lives to thrive, be happy, and successful! They also need opportunities to develop key skills such as empathy and grit. These important qualities are learned through face-to-face relationships and from life’s ups and downs—from the messy, indispensable, rollercoaster of REAL experience. For example, if we don’t teach, learn about, and practice empathy, we run the risk of not being able to solve our problems as a society—whether it’s bullying in schools or healing conflicts on a grander scale. Ponder this sad statistic . . .

As caring adults, we must protect the building blocks of kids’ vitality and wellness. Outdoor play, family ties, safe havens, creativity, and rituals—these critical assets are especially vulnerable in a time of unprecedented busyness and ever-present media influence. To assist parents, grandparents, educators, and counselors in helping their children navigate the complexity of fostering relationships, we have written an inspiring guide: Face to Face: Cultivating Kids' Social Lives in Today's Digital World. The more people who read our book or hear our authors speak, the sooner we can shift the consciousness toward the value of REAL relationships in our kids’ lives. 
  • Design and print Face to Face
  • Offer Face to Face discussion groups through schools, libraries, community centers, and congregations
  • Attend professional conferences and share our research and findings with colleagues working in the field
  • Promote Face to Face as the parent component of anti-bully programs

If we can exceed our goal and raise $23,000, we’ll be able to

  • Reach families nationally
  • Offer a monthly Webinar series (featuring the seven chapters of Face to Face) in which people all over the world can participate 

If we exceed all expectations and raise $32,000, we can change social norms . . .

  • Start a Parent Component to current anti-bully programs in 50 communities
  • Collaborate with 50 US professionals who work with families and are committed to reducing bullying and starting parenting groups
  • Give a set of 5 copies of Face to Face and free “How to Start Groups” Webinar trainings to kick off 50 parent discussion groups
  • Make our new book and talks by our authors available through scholarships to communities who otherwise would not have access to the information

Explore our resources: Family Empowerment Network and Creative Roots

                         

Family Empowerment Network, founded by pediatrician Kathy Masarie, is an organization based in Portland, OR, offering classes, talks, and workshops on various parenting topics. Face to Face: Cultivating Kids’ Social Lives in Today’s Digital World supplements FEN’s current books, Raising Our Daughters and Raising Our Sons, which have had rave reviews. One parent wrote this about Raising Our Daughters: “This is one of the best parenting books I've read by far. It has made me a better parent, and I'm sure my two daughters would agree.”

story:
So...

Destinee here!

I can't tell you how excited I am about this awesome once in a lifetime opportunity!

When my mom opened the envelope from People to People Ambassador's Program (a 50 year organization), my heart jumped! I know that there's a reason for me to go on this three week adventure!

Italy, Sicily, & Greece... Wow! I so incredibly love to learn and what is a better way to? I know that I will be more confident & self-assured after. This may even reveal more of the direction for my future. 80% of People to People alumni get into their first choice of college! 

I would be so amazingly honored for your help & support of me! Just imagine, to reach my goal, only 50 people need to give a 100$ or 100 people need to give 50$! I know God will provide for me all my needs. 

Please know that no amount is too small & every bit will help! So, just follow your heart & know that this 17 year old girl from Oklahoma would be truly grateful.

Love to you all...  

Destinee Wray Figler

story:
As a special education teacher, I try to get my students engaged in the world to make a difference. I also like to show the students how to have fun in life. A game that I played growing up in our family was bocce ball. Naturally I introduced this to my students as a game of recreation. They began to love it. A senior student of mine, Tim, decided that he wanted to make a Bocce Ball court for his senior project here at the school.

We are asking for contributions for the materials needed to build the Bocce Ball court. All of the labour will be done by students themselves. This is a great opportunity for the students to learn what it takes to build a lasting gift for Carver

Our fundraising goal is $1000

story:
The German Scout Association Saint George (DPSG) opens
up new domains of social commitment to young people. It encourages them to take
over responsibility and allows them to co-design the future. The practice of
political behaviour contributes to the development and stabilisation of
democratic culture.

By means of our diocese camp, we want to demonstrate
children, adolescents and young adults in the diocese Mainz the importance of a
city-community for every day life. Our diocese scout camp is themed:
“Scouttropolis – together we are city!” “Scouttropolis” will be a city built by
approximately 1000 scouts, developed and lived by them. Here, everyone will
have the chance to get involved with one’s skills, to discover new things and
to experience community at its best. From child to team leader – all of them
will be construction workers of this city. They will take the chance to try new
things and face adventures.

Despite the great effort of all the young adults in
our organisation, it is not possible to realise such a large-scale enterprise
by oneself. There are enough volunteers to realise the project. What we lack is
financial support.


 

Die pfadfinderische Pädagogik in der Deutschen Pfadfinderschaft St. Georg (DPSG) erschließt jungen Menschen Felder des gesellschaftlichen Engagements, ermutigt sie zur Übernahme von Verantwortung und ermöglicht ihnen die Mitgestaltung der Zukunft. Das Einüben und Erproben politischen Verhaltens ist ein Beitrag dazu, eine demokratische Kultur zu entwickeln und zu stabilisieren.

Durch unser Diözesanzeltlager 2014 wollen wir den Kindern, Jugendlichen und jungen Erwachsenen im DPSG Diözesanverband Mainz aufzeigen, wie wichtig eine Gemeinschaft „Stadt“ im täglichen Leben ist.

Unser Diözesanlager heißt "Scouttropolis - gemeinsam sind wir
Stadt!". Scouttropolis wird eine Stadt sein, die von 1000 Pfadfinderinnen
und Pfadfindern gemeinsam erbaut, entwickelt und gelebt wird. Hier hat jeder
die Möglichkeit sich mit seinen Fähigkeiten einzubringen, Neues zu Entdecken
und Gemeinschaft zu erleben. Von den Kindern bis zum Gruppenleiter – alle sind
Bauleute dieser Stadt. Sie wagen es, Neues auszuprobieren und stellen sich dem
Abenteuer.

Trotz des großartigen Einsatzes der jungen Erwachsenen in unserem Verband, ist es nicht möglich eine solche Großunternehmung alleine zu realisieren. Hierbei fehlt es jedoch nicht an ehrenamtlichen, sondern lediglich an finanziellen Unterstützern.
