MAVUNO Project began in 2009 with the first students expected no later than 2015.  Progress is ongoing, but pace is constrained by external support.  
100% of funds received go directly to support the initiative.  Please see below for more information or direct more specific inquiries to enactus@susqu.edu.  

The school is currently being constructed on a 62 acre plot of land in Chonyonyo Village, a constituent of Ihanda Ward in the Karagwe District of the Kagera Region of Tanzania.  As of the start of this campaign, brickwork and roofing for dormitory and teacher's buildings have been completed.  In addition, a well and water storage system has been constructed to ensure clean and safe drinking water for workers and future students.  Finally, construction of the canteen and kitchen is in progress; the foundation and walls have been completed and it is currently on the roofing stage.  All donations will support completion of the canteen and kitchen as well as the construction of classrooms, a biogas plant (biogas will be used for cooking), bathrooms, and toilets.We truly appreciate any donation you can offer. Your donation, no matter how small it is, will help the future education of Tanzanian women.  It will be one small step toward ending the vicious cycle of poverty in this region.  Donations received by MAVUNO will be used to purchase mainly industrial items, including but not limited to: cement, iron sheets/bars, nails, ceiling boards, and lime. Enactus is "a community of student, academic and business leaders committed to using the power of entrepreneurial action to transform lives and shape a better more sustainable world."  Susquehanna University Enactus is one of over 500 teams in the United States that combines passion for business and entrepreneurship with desire to serve and improve our communities locally, nationally, and internationally.  Supporting the MAVUNO Project is one of approximately 20 initiatives undertaken by our team this year.  Each year, our goal is to efficiently utilize our resources to positively impact as many people as possible.  Our results are then compared to our peers at an annual competition.  In the words of Enactus, when teams compete to serve those in need, "We all win."Of course you'll be
duly rewarded for your donations! Listed on the right side are the perks you
will receive from donating.  

$5 - Thanks for your support!
$15 - Facebook Shout Out
$25 - Proof from the Enactus President
$50 - The Shirt Off Our Backs
$150 - A Personal Touch From Us
Some of these perks
are limited, so hurry to get your donations in!Spread the word!  Even if you are unable to make a donation, we would love your support in raising awareness of our campaign and for MAVUNO Project.  Please share our campaign on your favorite social networking website!       Susquehanna University Enactus is raising funds on behalf of the MAVUNO Project as we consider ourselves strategic partners and investors in the initiative.  Our group does not directly represent the MAVUNO Project; however, 100% of funds received will go directly to supporting the initiative.

story:
Short Summary

We are The Focus Group, a collection of student and post baccalaureate photographic artists at the University of South Florida. We strive to make images that are compelling and have personal meanings that inform our bodies of work. It is very important to each one of us to gain knowledge about our process of making images. Networking is one of the main concerns in our profession as many of us wish to go to graduate school and become an art professional. It is integral to our success to attend conventions and conferences to reach out into the photographic community and make connections with other professional photographers in order to obtain our goals. We plan on attending the National Conference of the Society for Photographic Education in order to network and hopefully gain higher education materials.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $600 in order to completely pay for our trip to Baltimore, MD in order to attend the Society for Photographic Education's National Conference. We may have some funding from our University, however it is not enough to cover the full price of boarding fees for the twelve of us attending. We would like to stay in the hotel the conference is in and fit comfortable in three rooms instead of cramming six to a room. The $600 would help up attain that goal and board us all comfortably in three rooms. 

Being artists, we would love to reward your generosity with a print of your choosing. Sizing and price increments are as follows:

$15 Donation, 4x6 inch postcard print

$35 Donation, 8x10 inch print 

$50 Donation, 13x19 inch print

$65 Donation, 16x20 inch print

$80 Donation,  Two 13x19 inch prints

$85 Donation, Square 20x20 inch Scott Pierce Print

One of our photographers, Robert Dallas, would also like to offer a portrait session for a 4x5 print with a vintage look to the donation of $125.

The Impact

By donating to our cause, you will help a group of young professional photographers attain the goal of optimum networking opportunities and potentially helping a handful of us get into a graduate program at a top photography program. 

Attending a national conference about Photographic Education further deepens our passion to create art and expand our visual expression. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, please help us spread the word. There are many share tools on our page and we appreciate every contribution whether it be a donation or passing on the word.

Thank you for visiting our page and reading about our cause!

Images

For a larger image please visit the Gallery section at the top of the campaign.

story:
Summary

So, PDT IL Gamma has never had a parents' weekend.  I see this as a problem.  This year I am wanting to set up a weekend where we invite families to Monmouth College and show them our campus and actually expose them to our Fraternity and what it stands for.

Personally, I find this as a way to get the parents on our good side.  We can tell them about our chapter and what we are doing to help their son succeed in college and getting the best experience out of it.

The date we will hold this is Sunday, April 13th.

What I am planning on doing is having parents arrive and have a lackadaisical tour of campus, followed by SHORT talks from CAB members, SHORT talks from exec board, and other information about the Fraternity.

I also plan create a short video to show reasons why we joined Phi Delt.  This is material that can be used over and over. This can be used for years and allows us to possibly get some limelight from GHQ and a good recruitment video.

I also want us to create a short montage on how Phi Delt has helped the alumni achieve greatness.  We want to show that membership in Phi Delt doesn't end after graduation and the benefits never cease. 

Finally, I want to end it with a home cooked dinner provided by the men of Phi Delta Theta.  We will cook everything and provide a wonderful meal for our families.

What We Need & What You Get

I have set this at the minimum the website will allow me: $500.  That gives me $3.00 per plate saying everyone brings two family members, price for stamps, price for envelopes, price for beverages, price for dinnerware.

Now you're probably saying, "But Peacock, it says $500.  What happens if it goes over the $500 or doesn't hit $500?"  And I have answers for both.  The first question, money raised over $500 will be improving food amounts and quality.  If it's even over that, I will personally make sure the money rolls over into the next Parents' Club fund so we have a buffer for next year to help parents get involved.  The second question, if it doesn't have $500, we still will hold it.  I have arm wrestled our treasurer and made him give me his word he would work it out.

Now, I said I wanted alumni to voice their views of the Fraternity.  I want to formally invite alumni that donate to attend.  If $500 is raised, any alumni can come.  If you cannot donate, but want to attend or help out, It's as easy as Skyping me and giving me how Phi Delta Theta has helped you in life, whether undergraduate or professional.  Even quotes on the Facebook page is enough.  I will be putting these together with your profession and graduation date to show how successful our alumni are and what we can achieve.


Any questions, please get a hold of me on Facebook, email at apeacock@monmouthcollege.edu.  If you ask really, really nice, I may give you my number.

story:
KEY - Kauai Empowered Youth

is an Holistic Mentoring Organization for children age 11 to 18.

We use multi-cultural modalities to empower the youth, strengthen community, and deepen reverence for life. 

Our objective is to give the Youth tools to deal with their energy level, their emotions, their physical health, their family situations, and their fears about today's world so they become engaged in the community in positive ways.

Our goal is to raise $ 5550 By July 30th to be able to respond to the scholarships requests for 15 children to our upcoming summer camp


During the making of the most dynamic music video
they will experience :

  • Chakras Yoga for Teens
  • Qi Gong
  • Dance
  • Drumming and Rhythm
  • Media work
  • Organic food growing
  • Nutrition education
  • Anger Soul-utions
  • Conflict resolution
  • Rites of passage


Making it a most impact-full holistic life-changing experience...!

Our Mission:

The uniqueness of Kauai Empowered Youth is rooted within holistic wisdom and environmental inter-connectedness.
KEY is dedicated to contribute effectively to the resolution of violence, conflict and self-destructive behaviors in the teen population ( from drug and alcohol use, unplanned early teen pregnancy to high school drop out and suicide).
We reach to both Hawaiian ancestry and Hawaiian resident youth, and strive to contribute to a strengthening of harmony and understanding within our specific "melting pot".
In order for our Youth to feel truly empowered they need to experience both the original culture of the place we live in, and the positive aspects of the universal culture we are becoming.
By giving them access to Universal wisdom by means of yoga, expressive arts, deep ecology and sustainability education, we are preparing them to undertake the challenge and responsibility of adulthood in the times we are living in and the times to come.

"...By strengthening the inter-generational and multi-cultural bond within our community at large we will model to our children and to the world that sustainability comes from working together..." Yemaya Duby ~ creator of KEY

An holistic empowering approach:

K.E.Y. offers an outlet for creative expression, and programs that inspire conscious evolution and love in action.
As we present the youth with an exciting lifestyle we aim to empower them into clarity of judgment, organization skills, co-operation abilities and the knowledge to apply these gifts, and to restore health to our future and community.

Incorporating Youth councils, forums and meetings, putting the Youth “ in charge “ of the creation of events with an in- depth exposure to holistic lifestyles and Inter-generational sustainability, we believe in the success of our programs and upcoming facility.

Once a Youth has proven its commitment to the process we offer follow-up programs in coordination with some of Kauai’s businesses and organizations providing career exposure and counseling and offering support in direct interface with the world.

Yemaya's Story:
http://olakauaicom.fatcow.com/key/k-e-y-blog/my-story/

More infos? Visit our Page! www.kauaiempoweredyouth.com
Like us? FB page: Kauai Empowered Youth

Can't Afford a Contribution? Help Spread the Word!

Even if you can't contribute any funding, you can help spread the word on social networking sites (facebook, twitter, etc.), through emails, and through word of mouth. Every bit counts!

story:
P.L.A.Y in Southern Cone

"Practicing Languages, Advancing Youth"

My name is Siobhan, I am working with the Local AIESEC Committees across Southern Cone, (Argentina, Chile and Uruguay).

AIESEC is the worlds largest youth led, non-profit organisation and in Southern Cone we are running a project with a focus of "Practicing Languages, Advancing Youth in Southern Cone" in a fun environment!

I have been lucky enough to travel and meet many incredible people through  my time in AIESEC; engaging with interesting people from different cultures is what drives me to explore the world around me and develop myself in the process. But when I was learning languages in school, I never connected with why learning languages was important. I never connected languages with the incredible experiences I have been lucky enough to have while growing up. 

Project PLAY in Southern Cone aims to break that mindset in schools here, to show children that not only can learning languages be fun, but languages open up adventures and experiences that would otherwise not be possible. Languages allow us to engage with and learn about people, about cultures, about the world around us.

We will achieve this by bringing at least 45 volunteers from different countries around our international network to different Local Committees across Southern Cone for a 6 week project between December and February. They will connect with the children, play games, teach them about their cultures and encourage the children to share their own. The children will have fun, engage with different cultures and practice their english at the same time.

As an international organisation we have 60 years experience in sharing of cultures through sending people to 110 countries around the globe. Within this region our local commitees have experience in running successful education projects. We have the drive, passion and experience to run the kinds of sessions which will truly impact these children both in their language studies, and in their personal development.

But we cant do this alone, the volunteers will pay for their own flights and visas, but we need your support to pay for their food and travel to work, and to help cover the general running costs of the project, (this project is a not for profit project). Assuming these 45 volunteers each work with a group of 25 children during their 6 weeks here, the team will impact 1125 children!

If you donate, we will be happy to send you a virtual newsletter during the project, showing you exactly what we acheived thanks to your contribution. Our target is US$2000. But every penny counts, just US$2 represents one child impacted by this project! 

How can you help?

  1. Please donate US$2 today and help us make this project possible!
  2. Once you have donated, please share this page with your network and help us reach our target!

Thank you in advance for your support!

story:
This is Y!

Hey my name is Yasin Muhammad. I am 14 years old and live in Upper Darby,PA. I am campaigning to raise money in order to cover my tuition and expenses for the high school I've been accepted into for the 2012-2013 school year.

The school I've been accepted to is Youth Now on Top Academy, located in Philadelphia, PA. The school is geared toward the development of young entreprenuers like myself. I am a designer, my company name is YOUNG PRO. I design athletic clothes, shoes and accessories for the youth. My passion for this came about partly from playing sports myself. I am a track runner, tennis, football and basketball player. I am also a realist, not everyone makes it to the pros, even if I do I'll need something to do when I retire.

My hopes are to be able to start a clothing line for young people while I'm still young myself. Y-NOT Academy will not only help me do that, but also teach me what its like to start and maintain a business.

By contributing to my education campaign you will be helping me to secure a future for myself and investing in the possibility of greatness for all that I can help in the future.

YNOT

The school I will be attending Youth Now on Top Academy (Y-NOT) is the perfect environment for me to learn in because I will have a more personallized education as well as help with starting my business. I will be introduced to so many new things and opportunities. With this new school and new opportunity comes a new challenge for my family.....TUITION and how to pay for it.

What Y Needs & What You Get

Thats where your help comes in. I will need $5000 for yearly tuition, $830 for public transportation costs (10 months of septa trans passes), and just about $200 for school uniform shirts and supplies for the entire year and the rest for fees. All money collected will go to my Y-NOT education for 2012-2016. If I receive money over my goal it will go toward seed money for my clothing company YOUNG PRO.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I want to THANK EVERYONE for taking the time to consider my campaign. If for whatever reason you cannot help me financially, please share this campaign with your family and friends. And Please continue to support the RISE of a YOUNG PRO!

story:
Raspberry Jam Barcelona 2015

El próximo 11 de Abril se celebrará en el MOB (Makers of Barcelona) / FabCafe BCN, en la calle Bailen, 11 de Barcelona, un encuentro de entusiastas del mundo Maker en general y de la Raspberry Pi en particular.

El evento constará de charlas, talleres y un espacio para que los participantes puedan mostrar sus proyectos e intercambiar conocimientos y experiencias, el evento se celebrará de 11:00 a 19:00  y será gratuito.

Ayudanos! Que intentamos conseguir con esta campaña?
El evento que estamos organizando es totalmente gratuito, pero detrás hay una importante  inversión en tiempo y dinero de la gente que lo organiza y colabora con nosotros, por este motivo en el caso que estes interesando en asistir, estaríamos enormemente agradecidos si hicieses una pequeña donación en el momento de reservar tus entradas.
Para incentivar las donaciones hemos pensado en algunas recompensas simbólicas pero divertidas :)
También puedes ayudarnos dando soporte al evento en las redes sociales, usando el hashtag #rpijambarcelona o #rpijambcn

Quiero apuntarme!

Si quieres apuntarte al evento y hacer la reserva gratuita de tus entradas, debes ir a: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/entradas-raspberry-pi-jam-barcelona-15926580832

story:
Short Summary


“It is hard to understand addiction unless you have experienced it in yourself or someone close to you”

                                                                                           K. Hensley



We are trying to market this book, based on a true story about meth addiction in New Zealand, to as large an audience as we possibly can. We thought you might be able to help us.

My name is Chris von Roy, I live in Golden Bay, New Zealand and I need your support on this project. My background lies in science and medicine, particularly Immunology, and for over a decade of my life I have acted as a medical writer for various global publishing houses. I have worked on and edited several science textbooks, medical journals, biographies as well as fiction and poetry books. 

My passion lies in exploring hidden themes in society. Especially those themes that are too taboo to be discussed in mainstream news outlets, but that nonetheless hold the key to what makes societies function the way they do. 

The stuff that no one talks about.

Several months ago I was approached by a friend regarding a writing project. She had heard of my involvement with the NZ shark conservation book "Shark Man" (2014, Penguin Random House) and that I had acted as a ghost writer for book projects in the past.

This friend asked if I wanted to be involved in a more serious book project, one that dealt with drug addiction in its most damaging form. Without hesitating I agreed to take a look - what I found shocked and moved me profoundly. I was presented with several diaries from a kiwi mother who'd spent a large portion of her life married to a man who was addicted to the street drug known as crystal meth or 'P'. The diary accounts were so vivid and detailed that I questioned at first, whether or not I would be able to do the project justice and write a story that paid real tribute to the ghastly true life accounts. 

I decided to give it a go and worked on these diaries for several months. The book "A Life Less Lived" is the result of this work.

To date, this was the single most difficult project I have ever worked on. The subject matter was unbelievably intense and so hard to deal with that it gave me nightmares on most nights. I had no real personal experience to draw upon and seeing the story was going to be written from a woman's perspective, I also had to adjust my own mentality, world view and ultimately, writing style, in order to reflect this perspective.

What I found will not surprise you. This drug is the worst thing to ever have been created by our species. Crystal meth is the most addictive substance known to humankind and the real danger it poses is its stealth and 'supposed harmlessness'. A myth that is widespread among 'P' users. 

The drug doesn't barrel over its user's life like heroin does, nor cause everything to go amok in a heart beat like cocaine does, no crystal meth initially enters your life as a harmless mood enhancer, helping you have more energy at work and also keeping you awake and energetic for longer. Subtly feeding your brain way more dopamine - our 'happy' neurotransmitter- than it was intended for. And slowly it takes a stranglehold of everything that means anything to you in your life. Your personality, values, family, job, house and ultimately your livelihood.

'Carey', the original author of the book, initially wrote down and recorded all of her thoughts in her diaries with the intent of one day maybe giving them to a physician, so they could be fashioned into a self-help book for drug addicts. What has evolved from this idea is a book that harbours all that and more - it is not so much a self-help book, but more a brazenly honest account of a family whose life gets derailed by this drug. A wake-up call for anyone who knows anyone who may be involved in a similar situation.


What We Need & What You Get


Ok, so we have now finished the book. We deliberately put this campaign under "Educational" because that's how we see the book impacting its audience.
The book's protagonist "Carey" wanted this story written for people like her. When she first came into contact with the drug 'P' she knew nothing about it- there were no information handouts at the hospital nor was anyone in the news, radio or TV talking about the drug and its powerfully damaging effects on people's lives.
Carey wanted people to be given an insight into what life is like with this drug - describe the ups and the downs and put these into perspective,
We wanted this to be a passion project, so apologies for the lack of inventiveness when it comes to the "perks" - I guess being involved with something that could have such a positive effect on its readership and society, is a perk, yes even a blessing, in and of itself. So thank you!
The other aspect that makes the "perks" so difficult, is the fact that drug addiction is such a taboo topic and many people wouldn't want their name associated with it - so offering big "shout outs" or giving people 'producer' status as perks, never really made much sense. So we've kept it minimal.
The money we get from this campaign will be put towards funding a larger print run (1000+ books), helping with the distribution to libraries and rehab centres, communication and ultimately marketing efforts to get the book to as wide an audience as possible. 
Not only is the theme important, but the book itself is a good read and will entertain audiences as well as 'educate' them. A "win-win" if you will..

The Impact


There is so much stigma & taboo attached to this drug, and drugs in general, that people often do not know who to turn to when they get impacted - they shun their parents, close friends and even physicians in fear of being labelled or worse, castigated as a "drug user". Fear of losing one's job, reputation and the knowledge that it could affect the way one's family is treated, all results in our society being completely quiet about its existence (bar a few sensationalised news stories) and this has to change.

Our book aims to influence that scenario and bring the topic into a wider public discourse, where it belongs. Who knows how many women are in Carey's exact position right now, not knowing that walking away from their spouse and saving their family is the best option for them? 

We have approached the NZ Drug Foundation and are keen to be collaborating with them on getting the book into the right hands and making it available to a larger audience. Even those who have never experienced the drug or its users - the book could be an eye opener, for one of the nightmares about addiction to crystal meth is that it usually only becomes obvious to outsiders once it's too late.

We want our story to be read in every library, book store and drug counseling/rehabilitation clinic in New Zealand, and also the world.

For more information on the New Zealand Drug Foundation please visit here.


Risks & Challenges


Of course writing a book like this comes with some risks and challenges. The main one being that the identity of the main character and her family had to be concealed in such a way that it was not recognisable to anyone close to her. This was very difficult and challenging but I believe we managed to alter the story enough to be able to conceal identities whilst still remaining true to the actual story line.

The stigma that society throws at drug users and addicts is still very powerful. We wrote this book to help change that mindset - there is nothing wrong with being addicted to something, what is wrong, is when nobody steps up to help out the addict and worse, shuns them as if they were a stain on an otherwise pristine white shirt.

Marketing the story to the world could be a little daunting but not impossible. Through the NZ Drug Foundation, we aim to get into contact with other drug agencies around the world.

The fact that such a harrowing tale could ever have happened in New Zealand, one of the most beautiful countries on Earth, renders the story even more effective. You  may live in paradise, but it is your mind that gets to choose whether or not you recognise this. To date nearly 25 million people worldwide are addicted to methamphetamine - we want this book to be accessible to all of them!

New Zealand is up there with one of the highest per capita meth production and addiction rates in the whole world. 

So it makes sense that any "counter movement" should start here.


"A Life Less Lived" - A Short Synopsis


"My name is Carey and I was brought up in a small town in the South Island of New Zealand. I had a baby girl in my early 20’s and moved up north, where in due course I met my future husband, Darrin.

In our life before 'P' my husband and I were a normal ‘middle of the road’ kiwi couple with kids, a beautiful home and a business. We had a good relationship with Darrin’s ex wife and had his son for a night every week plus every second weekend. My daughter Laura and Michael got on great. We couldn’t ask for more.

I knew Darrin dabbled in recreational drugs when I met him, but he always seemed to be in control of the situation. I was not overly concerned when his cousin brought out some ‘crystal’ for us to try in 2004. I didn’t know anything about P then. My story goes on to detail my first hit of the drug and how after two weekends on it I could see the consequences immediately. It was affecting my relationship with my kids, my work and my health. 

Unfortunately Darrin fell in love with the drug, in part maybe because of the sexual nature of P. He started a journey that gradually took away everything he valued. I tried to keep the family ‘normal’ and stay off P, yet regularly fell victim to temptation even though the comedowns were unbearable. I have included how it affected our sex life as I believe this is a large part of why people get hooked. 

The reason for writing this book is that until a person on P is ready to give up, there is nothing you can do to ‘help’ them. You have to look after yourself and any children that are involved. The regrets I carry are immense. I exposed my daughter and step-son to the fringes of a low life environment and risked my own health and well being. My family and friends worried constantly about me. I should have gotten my kids out of that situation months earlier than I did. 

This drug creeps into your life, I want to fight back, and telling my story may help others see what direction their life may be heading. I want to help them fight back!"

Carey Boyd, July 2015


Thanks for reading and helping out..

story:
Verdun Organization for the Development of Arts and Culture (VODAC)

The Verdun Organization for the Development of Arts and Culture is a community driven non-profit organization whose goal is to establish an artistic and cultural centre and multi-purpose performance space in the heart of Verdun.

Verdun is home to a thriving artistic community however very few outlets exist for this community to get together and bring their talents to the public. In establishing a venue, we hope to provide this outlet and make a home for concerts, plays, community events and much more. 


Please Donate Generously

We are currently attempting to purchase a property located at 252 Rue Gordon in Verdun. We have already made an offer, but we can't do it on grants and bank loans alone. We need to move fast, and to do so, we need your help. If our offer is not accepted, we will act diligently to find another space in which to achieve our goal.


Where Your Money Is Going


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are an artist or a community organizer, you can write us a letter of intent stating that when we open a venue, you will plan to book it for events. 
  • If you are a local business owner in Verdun, you can write us a letter of support stating how a cultural centre and performance space would be a boon to your business and to the neighbourhood.
story_txt:
Verdun Organization for the Development of Arts and Culture (VODAC)
The Verdun Organization for the Development of Arts and Culture is a 
community driven non-profit organization whose goal is to establish an 
artistic and cultural centre and multi-purpose performance space in the 
heart of Verdun.
Verdun is home to a thriving artistic 
community however very few outlets exist for this community to get 
together and bring their talents to the public. In establishing a venue,
 we hope to provide this outlet and make a home for concerts, plays, community events and much more. 

Please Donate Generously
We are currently attempting to purchase a property located at 252 Rue Gordon in Verdun. We have already made an offer, but we can't do it on grants and bank loans alone. We need to move fast, and to do so, we need your help. If our offer is not accepted, we will act diligently to find another space in which to achieve our goal.

Where Your Money Is Going

Other Ways You Can Help



If you are an artist or a community organizer, you can write us a letter of intent stating that when we open a venue, you will plan to book it for events. 
If you are a local business owner in Verdun, you can write us a letter of support stating how a cultural centre and performance space would be a boon to your business and to the neighbourhood.

story:
En Français:

Bref résumé

L'Ecole ADE a besoin d'un coup de pouce !

Nous espérons pouvoir accumuler suffisamment d'argent pour pouvoir acheter des tables et des bancs pour les élèves de l'école.
Nous avons beaucoup de tables cassés et dans la plupart des classes les élèves sont à 5 ou 6 sur un seul banc!

La construction de ces bancs nous coute 500 USD, non-seulement parce qu'on à besoin de plus que 20 tables et bancs, mais aussi parce qu'ils seront en bois et fabriqués à la main. Ces tables et bancs dureront pour des générations.

Nous avons plusieurs idées avec lequel nous utiliseront le reste de l'argent:
  • réparer le toit (pour qu'il ne pleuve plus dans l'école) et réparer (cimenter) le sol. En échange nous voudrons demander au propriétaire de diminuer le loyer. (on aimerait aussi installer des lumières et des ventilos dans chaque classe.)
  • acheter des bics/stylos pour chaque classe, car il y a souvent des élèves qui n'ont pas les moyens d'acheter des bics/qui viennent à l'école avec des bics cassés. (chaque enseignant pourra prêter ces bics aux élèves et ensuite les récupérer à la fin du cours).
  • acheter des livres pédagogiques pour les enseignants (des livres qui pourront être utilisés pour faire leur cours, car les enseignants n'ont pas beaucoup de ressources.) Cela améliorait les cours énormément.
  • acheter des petites armoires pour chaque classe avec ses propres clés. (Chaque enseignant sera responsable pour l'armoire dans sa classe dans laquelle il aura plus facilement accès vers des fournitures scolaires.)
  • acheter des livres scolaires pour les élèves. Les enfants d'ADE ne possèdent que des cahiers et cela avancerait leur éducation, s'ils pourraient avoir leur propres livres scolaires, avec lesquels ils pourraient aussi étudier à la maison.

Notre école et ce dont elle a besoin

Dans la banlieue proche de Dakar, à Thiaroye, l'école communautaire ADE tente de fournir aux enfants du quartier une alternative entre école publique; insuffisante en places et en moyens, proposant des classes de primaire de 100 élèves, et écoles privées; trop chères pour les populations défavorisées. L'État sénégalais s'étant largement désengagé de l'école primaire, il laisse les structures privées ou communautaires faire face aux difficultés de financement.

Si les taux de scolarisation s'améliorent de plus en plus, la qualité de la formation, elle, ne suit pas nécessairement le mouvement. Le manque de ressources rend difficile à la fois la formation des enseignants et l'offre de matériel nécessaire à la scolarité des élèves. L'école, ayant pour principe d'accepter tous les élèves, même ceux ne pouvant payer qu'occasionnellement, est soumise à ces financements sporadiques alors que le loyer des locaux et les factures doivent être réglés chaque mois. Elle menace donc régulièrement de fermer, avec un risque important de déscolarisation pour les enfants, les autres écoles du quartier étant nettement plus chères (4000 XOF en théorie – avec arrangements possibles selon les situations de chacun-, contre 15 ou 20 000 XOF dans les autres écoles des environs).

L'école ADE est active pour chercher des solutions ! Elle postule aussi souvent que possible à des programmes d'aides divers ; elle fait aussi régulièrement appel à des volontaires, profitant de leurs compétences spécifiques pour l'administratif, la gestion informatique de la communication, mais aussi les cours de langue aux professeurs comme aux élèves, les cours d'alphabétisation, des enfants comme des parents, …


Elle aurait néanmoins besoin d'un coup de pouce ! Avant tout, les effectifs d'élèves ayant fortement augmenté ces dernières années, il s'agirait de remplir des salles vides de tables et de bancs, voire de remplacer ou réparer les anciens, tombant régulièrement et perturbant l'apprentissage et la concentration des élèves.

Ponctuellement, votre aide pourrait servir à compléter le paiement des factures et les salaires des professeurs lorsque les frais d'inscriptions fournis par les familles ne suffisent pas.

Tables-bancs :

15 (ou plus) x 25 000 Fcfa = 375 000 Fcfa = 576 euros



D'autres façons d'aider 

Vous pouvez toujours nous aider d'une autre facon!

  • Aidez-nous a faire la publicité! Partagez notre lien sur Facebook, parlez de notre projet a vos connaissances... SVP: même un petit partage qui vous prends quelques secondes nous aidera énormément!



In English:

ADE school needs a helping hand!

We hope to be able to receive enough money to be able to buy tables and benches for the students of the school.
We have many broken tables and benches and in most classes there are 4-5 students sitting on one single bench!

The construction of these benches would cost us 500 USD, not only because we need to buy more than 20 tables and benches, but also because these will be hand-made and out of wood. As a result these tables and benches will last for generations and will be a true investment for the school.

We have several ideas with which we could use the rest of the money:

  • repair the roof (so that it doesn't rain into the school anymore) and repair (cement) the ground. In exchange we would like to ask the owner of the school to reduce the rent. (We would also like to install lights and ventilators in each classroom.)
  • Buy pens for each class, as there are often students who don't have the means to buy any/or who come to the school with broken pens. (Every teacher would be able to lend pens and to then retrieve them at the end of the class.)
  • Buy educational books for the teachers (these books will be used for the classes, as the teachers don't have a lot of resources.) This would improve the classes a lot.
  • Buy small cabinets for each class with its own keys. (Every teacher will be responsible for the cabinet in their class through which they will more easily have acces to school supplies.)
  • Buy school books for the students. The children of ADE only have notebooks, thus if they would have school books, this would greatly imporve their education, as they would also be able to study at home.



Our school and what it needs:

In the nearby ghetto of Dakar, in Thiaroye, the community school ADE attempts to provide an alternative between public schools, insufficient in space and financial means with 100 students per class, and private schools, too expensive for the disadvantaged. The Senegalese state has primarily disengaged itself from primary education, so that community establishments have to independently confront their financial problems. Even though enrollment rates have improved more and more, the quality of educational training itself has not. The lack of resources not only makes it difficult to train the teachers but also to have the necessary material available for the schooling of the students. The school, whose principle is to accept every student, even those who can only pay occasionally, is confronted with sporadic funding even though rent and bills need to be paid every month. As a result the school is often upon the verge of closing its doors, which would mean that many children would not be able to have any access to education, due to the fact that all surrounding schools are private and thus expensive.

ADE is active in its search for solutions! It postulates as often as possible in a variety of different aid programs; the school also often appeals to its volunteers and thus profits from their specific skills to be used in administration, IT management communication, literacy courses, but also in language classes given to both students and teachers…

The school however, needs a helping hand!  The number of students has greatly increased in the last years, so that the school would also need to fill its empty classes with tables and benches and also replace the old ones, which fall down regularly and disturbs the learning and concentration of the students.

Promptly, your help could serve to complete the payment of bills and the salaries of the teachers, as the registration fees which the parents pay are not enough.

Tables and benches :

15 (ou plus) x 25 000 Fcfa = 375 000 Fcfa = 576 euros


Other ways to help

  • You can always help in another way! 
  • Share our link on Facebook, talk about our project to your friends... Please: even a small share which takes you a few seconds can help us enourmously!

acheter des livres pédagogiques pour les enseignants (des livres qui pourront être utilisés pour faire leur cours, car les enseignants n'ont pas beaucoup de ressources.) Cela améliorait les cours énormément.
acheter des petites armoires pour chaque classe avec ses propres clés. (Chaque enseignant sera responsable pour l'armoire dans sa classe dans laquelle il aura plus facilement accès vers des fournitures scolaires.)
acheter des livres scolaires pour les élèves. Les enfants d'ADE ne possèdent que des cahiers et cela avancerait leur éducation, s'ils pourraient avoir leur propres livres scolaires, avec lesquels ils pourraient aussi étudier à la maison. 



Notre école et ce dont elle a besoin

Dans la banlieue proche de Dakar, à Thiaroye, l'école
communautaire ADE tente de fournir aux enfants du quartier une alternative
entre école publique; insuffisante en places et en moyens, proposant des
classes de primaire de 100 élèves, et écoles privées; trop chères pour les
populations défavorisées. L'État sénégalais s'étant largement désengagé de
l'école primaire, il laisse les structures privées ou communautaires faire face
aux difficultés de financement. Si les taux de scolarisation s'améliorent de
plus en plus, la qualité de la formation, elle, ne suit pas nécessairement le
mouvement. Le manque de ressources rend difficile à la fois la formation des
enseignants et l'offre de matériel nécessaire à la scolarité des élèves.
L'école, ayant pour principe d'accepter tous les élèves, même ceux ne pouvant
payer qu'occasionnellement, est soumise à ces financements sporadiques alors
que le loyer des locaux et les factures doivent être réglés chaque mois. Elle
menace donc régulièrement de fermer, avec un risque important de
déscolarisation pour les enfants, les autres écoles du quartier étant nettement
plus chères (4000 XOF en théorie – avec arrangements possibles selon les
situations de chacun-, contre 15 ou 20 000 XOF dans les autres écoles des
environs).
L'école ADE est active pour chercher des solutions ! Elle
postule aussi souvent que possible à des programmes d'aides divers ; elle fait
aussi régulièrement appel à des volontaires, profitant de leurs compétences
spécifiques pour l'administratif, la gestion informatique de la communication,
mais aussi les cours de langue aux professeurs comme aux élèves, les cours
d'alphabétisation, des enfants comme des parents, …


Elle aurait néanmoins besoin d'un coup de pouce ! Avant
tout, les effectifs d'élèves ayant fortement augmenté ces dernières années, il
s'agirait de remplir des salles vides de tables et de bancs, voire de remplacer
ou réparer les anciens, tombant régulièrement et perturbant l'apprentissage et
la concentration des élèves. 
Ponctuellement, votre aide pourrait servir à compléter le
paiement des factures et les salaires des professeurs lorsque les frais
d'inscriptions fournis par les familles ne suffisent pas.
Tables-bancs :
15 (ou plus) x 25 000 Fcfa = 375 000 Fcfa = 576 euros





D'autres façons d'aider  

Vous pouvez toujours nous aider d'une autre facon!

Aidez-nous a faire la publicité! Partagez notre lien sur Facebook, parlez de notre projet a vos connaissances... SVP: même un petit partage qui vous prends quelques secondes nous aidera énormément!




In English: ADE school needs a helping hand!We hope to be able to receive enough money to be able to buy tables and benches for the students of the school.We have many broken tables and benches and in most classes there are 4-5 students sitting on one single bench!The construction of these benches would cost us 500 USD, not only because we need to buy more than 20 tables and benches, but also because these will be hand-made and out of wood. As a result these tables and benches will last for generations and will be a true investment for the school.We have several ideas with which we could use the rest of the money:
repair the roof (so that it doesn't rain into the school anymore) and repair (cement) the ground. In exchange we would like to ask the owner of the school to reduce the rent. (We would also like to install lights and ventilators in each classroom.)
Buy pens for each class, as there are often students who don't have the means to buy any/or who come to the school with broken pens. (Every teacher would be able to lend pens and to then retrieve them at the end of the class.)
Buy educational books for the teachers (these books will be used for the classes, as the teachers don't have a lot of resources.) This would improve the classes a lot. 

Buy small cabinets for each class with its own keys. (Every teacher will be responsible for the cabinet in their class through which they will more easily have acces to school supplies.)
Buy school books for the students. The children of ADE only have notebooks, thus if they would have school books, this would greatly imporve their education, as they would also be able to study at home. 






Our school and what it needs:In the nearby ghetto of Dakar, in Thiaroye, the
community school ADE attempts to provide an alternative between public schools,
insufficient in space and financial means with 100 students per class, and
private schools, too expensive for the disadvantaged. The Senegalese state has
primarily disengaged itself from primary education, so that community
establishments have to independently confront their financial problems. Even
though enrollment rates have improved more and more, the quality of educational
training itself has not. The lack of resources not only makes it difficult to
train the teachers but also to have the necessary material available for the
schooling of the students. The school, whose principle is to accept every
student, even those who can only pay occasionally, is confronted with sporadic
funding even though rent and bills need to be paid every month. As a result the
school is often upon the verge of closing its doors, which would mean that many
children would not be able to have any access to education, due to the fact
that all surrounding schools are private and thus expensive. 
ADE is active in its search for solutions! It
postulates as often as possible in a variety of different aid programs; the
school also often appeals to its volunteers and thus profits from their
specific skills to be used in administration, IT management communication, literacy
courses, but also in language classes given to both students and teachers… 

The school however, needs a helping hand! 
The number of students has greatly increased in the last years, so that the
school would also need to fill its empty classes with tables and benches and
also replace the old ones, which fall down regularly and disturbs the learning
and concentration of the students. 
Promptly, your help could serve to complete the
payment of bills and the salaries of the teachers, as the registration fees
which the parents pay are not enough. 
Tables and benches :
15 (ou plus) x 25 000 Fcfa = 375 000 Fcfa = 576 euros
Other ways to help
You can always help in another way!  

Share our link on Facebook, talk about our project to your friends... Please: even a small share which takes you a few seconds can help us enourmously!

story:
The Greek economic crisis is in all of the headlines and has become a major issue in Europe and around the rest of the world.

As always when a crisis of this magnitude takes places, there are always hidden and unseen victims. In this case the children are the ones who are feeling the brunt of the situation.

Children do not have a say, they cannot make decisions and they have to live with the situation that the adults they rely on have created.

Motivated by our daughter, we decided to do what we can to improve the situation for children in Greece, hence our campaign to raise enough money to print and distribute much needed school notebooks for the children of Greece.

The deep economic crisis which scourges Greece over the last 5 years, has infected the lives of most Greeks in the most profound negative way. The situation is completely hopeless and has finally come to a devastating conclusion. Unemployment is now at 28% and many people simply cannot make ends meet. Many Greeks are now deprived of the essentials and basic necessities of life.

We run a family business in Greece, a printshop that specializes in 3D printing, Flip-Flop images and Animation.  
Our daughter Nicole, bearing in mind the family business and aware of the situation in our country came up with the wonderful idea of how we could help out. Nicole suggested we print and provide notebooks for children free of charge, so that everyone could have a the essentials for school.
Although an overwhelming idea, we thought it was worth a try, we know that many parents were struggling and the thought of children suffering at such a basic level was distressing,
so here we are with our campaign live on Indiegogo, asking for you to help us to achieve this rather large goal of printing 40,000 notebooks.

Our company is also engaged in producing 3D products such as postcards, magnets and rulers along with large format 3D printing and digital banners, textile and canvas.
The knowledge and equipment available to us though the business allows us to provide great Greek style perks that you will enjoy, a small token of our gratitude, to all of you who are willing to make a donation to help us meet our goal.

Your contribution will help us get to our goal of printing and distributing 40,000 notebooks, with an average primary school having 300 students we will be able to help 40 – 60 Greek schools.

Of course everything will depend on the success of this campaign and we sincerely hope from the bottom of our hearts that we can exceed our goal and help even more children by providing them with essential tools for their education, and make their wishes come true.

Whatever the outcome we are determined to donate 1000 notebooks to 500 children, which will make Nicole really very proud of her family.

story:
Hey friends (and friends of friends, thanks to the magic of Facebook!),

I'm Joni.

Here is the abbreviated version of what you need to know:

I'm making a trip to Kenya next month and visiting my friend Katy, who is working with an organization called Omwabini. (Click here to learn about their orphanage and community work.)

Katy made a recent discovery: when asked to talk to some young women about sanitary products, she realized that she was probably the ﬁrst person to ever have a discussion with them about menstruation because they had all lost their mothers when they were young. A 15 minute training turned into a 2 hour dialogue about the heartbreaking struggle surrounding this topic. 

She shared these stories with me and we continued to dig deeper into this issue together. We discovered that girls in Kenya are missing 20% of their education because they lack resources to manage their period. For personal stories about this unspoken struggle, watch this video. Even just two minutes of watching will give you a clear picture of the reality for these girls.  

 

These stories and statistics broke my heart and piqued my interest. I'm a social worker in Grand Rapids, Michigan where I support moms during their pregnancy and as they raise their young ones. I love my job and am passionate about helping women understand their bodies during this season of their lives. This passion led to researching how to support the young women at Omwabini.

There is a great solution!

Let me introduce you to... Ruby Cup!(click here, explore their site, and learn what they are all about!)

They have a fantastic mission: To provide a sustainable and healthy menstrual hygiene solution to women and girls world wide..

More fun facts about Ruby Cup:

-the company is based in Kenya

-they provide education and support with their product

And get this . . .

-this one time purchase will provide 10 whole years of worry free menstruation management. We're talking middle school through college without missing one day of school because of this problem!

 

Here's what we want to do for the girls at Omwabini...

We want to raise $1,500.

With your contribution, we will be able to provide the following for over 100 girls:

-holistic reproductive health education

-10 whole years of menstruation management via a menstrual cup

-the products necessary to keep this menstrual cup clean.

In the most basic way, here is the impact your contribution will make:

$12 = menstrual cup and education for 1 girl

$25 = menstrual cup and education for 2 girls

$50 = menstrual cup and education for 4 girls

$150 = menstrual cup and education for 12 girls

 

What we love about this project is that Omwabini and Ruby Cup are both investing in the lives of these girls. Omwabini will continue to provide education and vocational support and Ruby Cup will continue connecting with girls in this community. It's an ongoing relationship.

It is our hope that through this project Omwabini will be a community of women empowered to continue in their education. A community of women with less shame and stigma attached to this normal, beautiful function of their bodies.

Other Ways You Can Help

We believe that there is power in sharing. We would be honored if you shared this project with your family, friends, coworkers, classmates, and the stranger next to you at the coffee shop.

Indiegogo is so awesome that they provide sharing tools--please use these!

Thanks Friends. Let's do this!

Just a heads up...If we do not reach our goal, the money that is contributed will still go to Omwabini to purchase Ruby Cups for as many girls as possible.

story:
Short Summary

I am a Student Pilot from Nairobi, Kenya in East Africa and I am training towards a Private Pilot Licence (PPL).

I have been attempting to join flying school since the year 2010 and I was not successful due to budget constraints until March 2012 when I got a non-formal job in my city’s local authority and managed to save up enough money to pay for Ground School. In a span of one year and six months, I have managed to accomplish the following:

·  Covered extensive Ground School for both Private Pilot Licence(PPL) and Commercial Pilot Licence (CPL).

·  Passed the PPL ground examinations.

·  Passed the CPL ground examinations.

·  Secured an opportunity as an Assistant Ground Instructor at my flying school.

·  Built 16 flight hours towards a Private Pilot Licence (PPL).

I now work as an Assistant Ground Instructor at my flying school and save all the money I earn and pay for flight training. This mode of operation has brought me this far but it is not sustainable because I can only afford two hours of flight instruction in a month. Therefore, I am in need of funding to enable me fly in a consistent manner and complete my training towards a Private Pilot Licence (PPL).

I am interested in using my flying skills by participating in wonderful causes such as: wildlife conservation. In Kenya, especially this year, wildlife is under serious threat in the form of poaching. This is particularly so for elephants which are targeted for ivory. The practice has adverse effects on the population of these animals and if not stopped, it will lead to the extinction of elephants in a few years to come.

In that regard, there are a number of initiatives that have been put up by various wildlife conservation initiatives in order to address this challenge. General Aviation aircraft are used in tracking the animals and this is important as it identifies their position and in case they move out of the conservancies, quick response to return them is possible before they get exposed to poachers.

With a Private Pilot Licence (PPL), I will be in a position to volunteer and make my contribution towards a cause that is dear not only to my country but to humanity.

What I Need & What You Get

I intend to raise $5,000 in order to complete the remaining bit of my flight training towards a Private Pilot Licence (PPL) which will afterwards enable me to be in a position to participate in wildlife conservation activities.
By supporting me in this cause, you stand to receive the wildlife merchandise in the form of: paintings, branded t-shirts and key holders.

The Impact

This success of this campaign can be summarised as:

1.   In my country, there are virtually no flight training scholarship opportunities as compared to the U.S. Most people like myself, look up to these opportunities in the U.S and most of the time fail to win any scholarship as majority are reserved for U.S citizens only. The success of this campaign will enable me to accomplish a goal that has been so evasive for a while.

2.  The success of this campaign will not only be of benefit to me in so far as a Private Pilot Licence (PPL) is concerned, it will be a boost towards the various wildlife conservation initiatives since I am going to be in a position to make my contribution with my flying skills. It will go a long way in safeguarding the population of wildlife which is an asset to future generations.

3.  East Africa is famous for its Wildlife Safaris. A key component of this industry is the wild animals. Conservation of these wild animals will ensure that there are animals left for people such as you to come and enjoy during your holiday.

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way in which you can contribute is by spreading the word about this campaign among your friends.

story:
Description

After having a stint of homelessness and dropping out of high school earlier this year, Ashana came to San Francisco to visit her big sister (from Big Brother Big Sisters) and was inspired by the tech scene in Silicon Valley to go back to college and study computer science.  She visited Google, Facebook, Twitter, Uber, Dropbox, FundersClub, Yelp, Soldsie, Safe Shepherd, Code 2040, Code for America, Learn Capital, Black Girls Code, and more.  Her dream job is to be a front-end developer at one of these companies :)  In the last 6 months, she has:

  • Finished her GED
  • Completed her high school diploma
  • Taken her SATs
  • Written college essays and applied to colleges
  • Interned at Learn Capital, a venture capital firm that invests in education startups
  • Interned at Black Girls Code, a non-profit that teaches minority girls computer science
  • Taken an interest in computer science and begun teaching herself to code on CodeAcademy
  • Gotten into University of San Francisco, where she will be studying computer science!

 

What We Need - $2K target (of $78K total gap)

Ashana has come so far, the last hurdle is paying for college.  University of San Francisco has given her financial aid, but there is a gap.  As the extended family and friends of Ashana, we want to reduce this gap as much as possible to reduce the financial burden Ashana will have.

There is a $78,000 gap between the cost of college and financial aid.  $78,000 includes tuition, room & board, books, and basic dorm/living expenses.

We are running this campaign of $2,000 to chip away at this.  We are extremely grateful for any contribution but of course will not turn away additional funds above the $2,000 target.

 

What You Get

In exchange for your support, here are some rewards!

  • $25 - Hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
  • $50 - "I supported Ashana" Tshirt + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
  • $100 - Invitation to Ashana's "Going Away to College Fundraising Gala" in San Francisco September 6th + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
  • $150 - Invitation to one-on-one lunch with Ashana where she'll demo her first apps she has built in her freshman CS class + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
  • $300 - 5 hours of Ashana doing chores for you + invitation to Ashana's "Going Away to College Fundraising Gala"  in San Francisco September 6th + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana.  (Chores can be dog-walking, house cleaning, picking up dry cleaning, you name it!)
  • $500 - Personalized rap on the topic of your choice written, rapped and video recorded by Ashana (Ashana is good!  You can send in specific phrases to be included if you want) + Invitation to Ashana's "Going Away to College Fundraising Gala"  in San Francisco September 6th + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
  • $5,000 - Sponsor Ashana for 1 semester.  Get personalized updates on her semester progress.  Talk to Ashana about how she is doing.  Pay for an entire semester tuition of classes (not inc room + meals).  Contact us to ask what you'd like for this sponsorship, we are flexible!

 

The Impact

Ashana will be the first in her family to go to college.  Reducing her debt as much as posible will increase her chances of finishing and getting off to a strong start in her adult life.  Let's show her our support and love as we send her off to college by chipping away at what she will need to pay off!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with your friends on facebook and twitter to spread the word.  Thank you for your support!

$300 - 5 hours of Ashana doing chores for you + invitation to Ashana's "Going Away to College Fundraising Gala"  in San Francisco September 6th + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana.  (Chores can be dog-walking, house cleaning, picking up dry cleaning, you name it!)
$500 - Personalized rap on the topic of your choice written, rapped and video recorded by Ashana (Ashana is good!  You can send in specific phrases to be included if you want) + Invitation to Ashana's "Going Away to College Fundraising Gala"  in San Francisco September 6th + hand-written thank you post card from Ashana + thank you video from Ashana
$5,000 - Sponsor Ashana for 1 semester.  Get personalized updates on her semester progress.  Talk to Ashana about how she is doing.  Pay for an entire semester tuition of classes (not inc room + meals).  Contact us to ask what you'd like for this sponsorship, we are flexible!

 
The Impact
Ashana will be the first in her family to go to college.  Reducing her debt as much as posible will increase her chances of finishing and getting off to a strong start in her adult life.  Let's show her our support and love as we send her off to college by chipping away at what she will need to pay off!



 
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this with your friends on facebook and twitter to spread the word.  Thank you for your support!

story:
Hey Past Panthers!

Thank-you for taking the time to find out how you can help us help Meghan!

As most of you know, we are hosting a fabulous St. Pete's get together to celebrate 10 years since graduating! Everyone is welcome! For more info on that click here

Instead of hosting a huge expensive soiree - we are keeping it light and simple so everyone can enjoy a great night while supporting a fellow graduate living and coping with CF ( Cystic Fibrosis ). 

Meghan Manuel was diagnosed with CF when she was just 11 months old. She is now a super mom raising three beautiful children (Aurora, Savanna and Grayson) amongst the everyday struggle and painful effects of CF.  In brief, her lungs fill up with a thick sticky mucus, which is an ideal breeding ground for bacteria - making it difficult to fight off infection. That same mucus blocks and destroys the digestive system. 

Meghan's daily routine includes: 3 nebulized treatments, chest physiotherapy to clear mucus, daily and nightly internal tube feeding, diabetes management, and numerous medications. This means Meg is constantly fighting off infections, as well as complications that arise when dealing with CF. As the disease worsens, it makes it very difficult to work.

Our goal is to raise awareness and give some comfort to a past panther in her fight against CF by donating all proceeds directly to Meg and her family.  

We can't do this without you and as the saying goes... a little goes a long way!!!

Please, if you find yourself in the Barrie area on October 5 - COME!

I hope this finds you all well.

You can read Megs blog here!

For more information on Cystic Fibrosis, please click here.

story:
Who We Are

Snohomish County Music Project engages a network of passionate musicians to promote artistic citizenship within our community, expand access to music education in our schools, and use the power of music therapy to improve the lives of our most vulnerable community members - at risk youth, veterans and senior citizens. We have proudly reinvented ourselves by using music as a force for positive changes within our community. Our intention is to create an environment for musical expression while highlighting urgent needs and providing grassroots solutions to community problems. 

Music fosters individuality, creativity, and a deep sense of fulfillment in young people and, as such, should be an essential part of our educations system. Yet budget cuts continue to reduce the availability of music education in our schools thus denying students a holistic educational experience and access to important platforms for creativity and self-expression. Expanding access to music education in our schools has never been more important.

How we are doing it:

  • Building demand for music programs among children and families.
  • Building support for music programs among community leaders.
  • Building capacity to help schools increase music programs.

What is Link Up

Link Up is a program provided in partnership with the famed Carnegie Hall, which pairs orchestras across the country with elementary students at schools in their local communities to explore orchestral repertoire through hands-on music instruction and interactive experience. Through Link Up, participating music teachers in the Marysville School District instruct 4th and 5th grade students to play recorders using curriculum developed and provided by Carnegie Hall. This introduces students to masterworks and teaches them how to read, recite and perform orchestral music in an environment which encourages the celebration of the arts as an integral component of our everyday lives. 

The culmination of Link Up comes with the live concert, at which students accompany a professional orchestra performing the pieces they have learned in school. Just imagine the sound and excitement of some of the region's best musicians performing with a 1,000 student recorder section. Additional opportunities to explore our community's music vendors and services are made available after the performance. This year's performance will be held at 6:30 p.m. on May 22, 2014 at Marysville Pilchuck High School Gymnasium. 

Last year, more than 1,300 students participated in Link Up in classrooms across Snohomish County and the assessment of the program showed student participants to be highly engaged, well prepared, and excited to perform.

What Link Up does for our children:

  • Introduces them to orchestral ensembles.
  • Shows them how practice and perseverance leads to improvement.
  • Gives them an opportunity to experience teamwork.
  • Helps them express themselves creatively.
  • Makes them feel a part of a professional orchestra.

What people are saying about Link Up:

School Administrator: Link Up “greatly enlivened our elementary music program. Link-Up and SCMP brought together our elementary music teachers, a dedicated group, for professional development in a recorder curriculum. The Project enhanced the collegiality and esprit de corps of the music teachers, who were enthused to collaborate with SCMP to bring these opportunities to 1,300 district students.”

Music Teacher: “To have our community provide this program is incredible. When school music programs are being reduced or even eliminated this sends a clear signal that the community values music programs. This will help a lot when we have to justify our programs to keep funding. I think this is one of the best music programs I have seen in my career.”

Parent: “I’ve never seen a live orchestra before. I think I would like to go to a concert again.” “My son was really into this. He practiced at home a lot and was really excited to play with the orchestra.”

Students: “It was really cool playing with the orchestra.” “I want to learn to play violin.” “I love music.” “

Conductor: “The program provided a unique and powerful musical experience for fourth and fifth graders in the Marysville school district. Students were very proud to be playing along with a full symphony orchestra and left the concert excited for next year’s Link Up. At the conclusion of the concert, I asked the students if they wanted to keep playing music in middle school. Every student responded with an enthusiastic "Yes!" Link Up is an amazing opportunity for students and helps build strong musicians and music lovers in the world. I'm very happy to be a part of a project that creates such a buzz of excitement around music and art of various genres and styles.”

Why We Need Your Help

As a non-profit community arts program, our budget is contingent on the support of others. To keep Link Up in our schools and sustain its presence in the community, we ask for support to cover the costs of program staff, instruments, and the culminating interactive concert with a professional orchestra.

We know that not everyone is able to contribute funds to our campaign, and we equally appreciate any efforts you make to help us get the word out. Please share our campaign link in support of our project to help us get noticed. 

Why It’s Important

In 2010, Northwestern University scientists produced a compilation of research findings from scientists all over the world. The bottom line to these studies was that musical training has a profound impact on other skills including speech and language, memory and attention, and even the ability to convey emotions vocally. 

The Northwestern researchers concluded their findings with the following: "The effect of music training suggests that, akin to physical exercise and its impact on body fitness, music is a resource that tones the brain for auditory fitness and thus requires society to re-examine the role of music in shaping individual development. “

Other studies have suggested that music education programs help children develop  self-confidence / self-esteem, ethical and aesthetic values, discipline, organization and time coordination, spirit of solidarity and fraternity, awakening of sensibility, value of teaching others, empathy, personality, leadership, learning principles, sense of commitment, responsibility, generosity, dedication to others, sense of individual contribution to collective goals, a noble identity, intellectually, perseverance, punctuality, creativity, ethic of self and community improvement, goal setting, and hand/eye/ear coordination. 

It is imperative that we continue the generation-old tradition of teaching music to our young people. The time is NOW to help raise awareness about the importance of music education! Please help us ensure that our community's youngest citizens continue to receive this vital part of their cultivation.

Thank you for your consideration!!

story:
The Student Nutrition Organization of San Diego State University is planning its “2nd Annual Kids Eat Right Dinner Gala and Silent Auction”.  The Kids Eat Right campaign supports the efforts of the White House to end the childhood obesity epidemic within a generation. This admirable cause educates, advocates, and demonstrates healthy lifestyle choices in order to prevent chronic disease from a young age. Our organization has adopted these same values and is passionate about this cause. We need your help to ensure the success of this event. We would appreciate your support and sponsorship.
         This event serves two purposes: To educate the community of the importance of nutrition education for at risk youth and also raises funds for the programs of Kids Eat Right.  


This memorable evening will be held at the historic Hall of Champions in San Diego's Balboa Park on November 7th, 2014. In it’s first year the event garnered national recognition from The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. Our goal is to expand the awareness of childhood obesity and its growing importance on our community by raising funds to support the Kids Eat Right campaign.    


We appreciate ANY help given, big or small from any contributor.  Every little bit makes a difference.


Sponsorship Levels

Bronze $100: Program mention and Website Ad

 Silver $250: promo flyers and everything above

   Gold $500: banner at event and everything above

Platinum $1000: speaking time, media mentions and everything above

*Please email us at the address below to become one of these sponsors

           

This campaign is to ensure we can fund the event.  All profits from the night of the event will be donated to the Kids Eat Right.  Without you this event would not be possible. Any questions can be addressed to SNOdinnergala@gmail.com.

story:
Who Am I?


A lot of you won't know me personally, so allow me to introduce myself to you:
My name is Roxy Malyon. I'm an extremely passionate 23 year old South African. Unlike a lot of the people I know, I don't come from money. Everything I own, I've had to buy myself.
For as long as I can remember, I've always love drawing and anything art related. Now, I know what you're thinking: "How is makeup anything like art?" but, you see, it is an art. A face is a canvas, and putting makeup on isn't as simply as I had first imagine.
After watching many YouTube tutorial videos, I decided that that is what I wanted to do. I wanted to learn makeup. Professionally. I want to make brides glow on their wedding day, I want to create artistic looks for runway shows. I want to create beauty. 

What I Need & What You Get:


  • Products and courses are extremely pricey in South Africa, and in order to be the best at what I do, I need to raise $1,500 - this amount covers the remainder of my tuition fees & a few necessary products that I've yet to purchase for my kit due to prices. 
  • I shall reward contributors with different sorts of art (pencil sketches, creative display photographs, etc.)
  • Should I not reach my entire goal, the funds will still go towards my tuition fees. But, should I raise MORE than I need, funds will be divided and donated to the following: a homeless shelter, children's hospital, SPCA & a struggling orphanage.

I know you're probably thinking that this is a silly cause to fund, but to me it's the world. I've always tried to help people where I can. I've donated my own eggs to several infertile couples in hope that my small contribution can change their lives.

There is nothing more amazing than the feeling you get from knowing that you have helped make someone's dreams come true.


    Obstacles I've Had To Overcome So Far:


    I wish I could say that being a student is easy, but it isn't. Especially not while working 2 jobs (and as many other odd jobs as possible) to pay for my fees. I don't have a car, and public transport isn't the safest in my city at night. 
    I've always been the kind of person that has made a plan, but I often feel that having to work as frequently (often resulting in having to leave college early to get to work) is getting in the way of my studies. 
    I'm fighting, and stressing, every month to make my college payments. It's one of the most difficult things I've had to experience so far. 

      Other Ways You Can Help:

      If you can't contribute, but would like to help in some way, please:

      • Share my campaign with your friends on social media platforms, or even via email.

story:
My name is Christopher McGovern.  I am a graduate of Digital Arts at Ex'Pression College in Emeryville, CA, a musician, music producer and audio engineer. I am currently teaching a Music Production and Engineering course at Oakland School for the Arts, and hope to grow the program into an emphasis within the school. 

    Oakland School for the Arts is a public charter school located in the historic Fox Theater in Downtown Oakland, serving 668 middle and high school students from all over the Bay Area, tuition-free. OSA combines traditional academic curricula with immersive arts training in one or the following ten arts emphases: Visual Arts, Dance, Theatre, Vocal Music, Instrumental Music, Digital Media, Circus Arts, Literary Arts and Production Design. Currently the Music Production and Engineering course is a pilot program under the wing of the Instrumental Music Department, but my hope is that we can build the studio and the workstations needed to launch Music Production and Engineering as a full emphasis offered to OSA’s high school students. 

What We Need & What You Get

To get the Music Production and Engineering emphasis off the ground I am hoping to raise half the total money needed to complete the studio and the workstations.  My goal is to raise $25,000 to cover the cost of the computers and their peripherals. If we can put together the computer workstations alone it would have a meaningful impact on the curriculum and give the students an interactive, hands-on experience. Any funds raised over the projected goal would be put towards the remainder of the programs needs and help to create a sustainable emphasis within the school. 

To build a recording studio and workstations for the students we would need:

•  Computers, Keyboards, Video Monitors

•  Audio Interfaces, MIDI controllers, Recording Software

•  Microphones, Cables, Microphone Stands

•  Studio Monitors, Acoustic Treatments

Join our New Sponsors in building OSA's Studio and get these great perks!

•  10 pass to any Touchstone Climbing Gym!

•  Rudy's Can't Fail Cafe gift cards!

•  OSA T-shirts and Hoodies 

•  OSA CD's with personal dedications


What This Means to OSA and the Students

Helping us to grow the Music Production and Engineering emphasis at OSA would add another facet to the dynamics of the school's creative environment. Offering Music Production and Engineering will provide access to instruction, equipment and encouragement that may not be available elsewhere in the students lives. It would create an avenue for the students to compose, collaborate and contribute to the musical creative process. In addition it would allow the MP&E emphasis to assist in recording and engineering projects of its sister programs.  

Other Ways to Help MP&E/OSA

We understand that times can be tight, maybe you can contribute by word of mouth!

•  Pass this along on your social media/email list

•  Share this with potential students/families

•  Share the link where you think the right people will see it

•  Donate gear, or pass the link along to someone you think may be able to. 

Thank you!
